revision.comment: Intro
revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Aage Gudmund Hatt | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 1 October 1884 | birth_place = Vildbjerg, [[Denmark]] | death_date = 27 January 1960 | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = Danish | fields = [[Cultural geography]] | workplaces = [[University of Copenhagen]] | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = H.P. Steensby | influenced = | awards = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | footnotes = }}
Professor '''Aage Gudmund Hatt''' (1 October 1884 – 27 January 1960) was a [[Danish people|Danish]] [[Archaeology|archaeologist]] and [[Cultural geography|cultural geographer]]. He was a professor of cultural geography at the [[University of Copenhagen]] from 1929 through 1947.<ref name="geopoliticsandtrial">{{cite web|url=http://www.geography.dur.ac.uk/conf/criticalgeopolitics2008/ConferenceTimetable/AbstractsforOpenSessions/HenrikGutzonLarsen/tabid/2880/Default.aspx|title=‘As a political geographer - and as a Dane’: the geopolitics and trial of Gudmund Hatt|last=Larsen|first=Henrik Gutzon|work=geography.dur.ac.uk|publisher=Durham University, Department of Geography|accessdate=24 July 2010}}</ref> Also an [[Ethnology|ethnologist]], he was the first person to systematically inventory cultural similarities and differences amongst northern peoples.<ref name="Cunliffe">{{cite book|last1=Cunliffe|first1=Barry|last2=Davies|first2=Wendy |last3=Renfrew|first3=Colin |title=Archaeology: the widening debate|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jkhgPgH330YC&pg=PA102&dq=Gudmund+Hatt&hl=en&ei=wnVKTNWfK5KksQPisPlI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=Gudmund%20Hatt&f=false|series=British Academy Centenary Monographs|year=2002 |publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0-19-726255-4|page=102}}</ref>
==Early years== Hatt was born in [[Vildbjerg]] - before 2007 in [[Trehøje Municipality]], from 2007 in [[Herning Municipality]] - Denmark, and studied there through 1904. His father was the local teacher. In 1905, he went to the United States and lived among the [[Cherokee]] Indians in [[Oklahoma]] for a year, which led him to study ethnography at [[Harvard University]] from 1906 to 1907.<ref name="Mahler">{{cite web|url=https://nordligeverdener.natmus.dk/uploads/media/Skin_Clothing_From_The_North_01.pdf |title=Two Hatts and the Article Skin Clothing |last=Mahler |first=Ditlev L. |year=2010 |work=Skin Clothing from the North: Abstracts from the Seminar at the National Museum of Denmark November 26–27, 2009 |page=14 |accessdate=24 July 2010 |location=Copenhagen }}</ref> Returned to Denmark, he lectured on [[Native Americans in the United States]] and their former way of living, and began his studies under [[Hans Peder Steensby]], ethnographer and professor of geography at the [[University of Copenhagen]].
In 1911, he married the painter and ethnographer [[Emilie Demant Hatt|Emilie Demant]], who had developed a keen interest in [[Sami people]].<ref name="Harvard ">{{cite book|last=Harvard College (1780- ). Class of 1910|first=|title=Secretary's third report|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ycknAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA375&dq=Emilie+Demant+Hatt&hl=en&ei=UOVHTJPpDJKisQOyt5SoCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCkQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=Emilie%20Demant%20Hatt&f=false|edition=Digitized Jun 4, 2008|year=1910|publisher=Crimson Printing Co.|page=375}}</ref> In the same year, he began doctoral studies of Arctic people, including an ethnographic study of [[Lapland (region)|Lapland]]. For two years, between 1912-1914, Hatt and Demant visited northern [[Sweden]] several times, collecting ethnographic materials for the [[National Museum of Denmark]].<ref name="Mahler" /> This research formed the basis for his 1914 doctoral thesis, ''Arctic skin clothing in Eurasia and America'' when he noticed the cut in the clothing of Arctic peoples was based on whether they fished marine life or hunted in loose snow. From this, he theorized that two cultures developed in the [[Arctic]], one that was land-locked and another that was coastal. In 1914, while a fellow of [[The American-Scandinavian Foundation]], he studied at [[Columbia University]].<ref name="TheAmerScand">{{cite book|editor=Henry Goddard Leach|title=The American-Scandinavian review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=do19AAAAMAAJ&pg=RA5-PA41&dq=Emilie+Demant+Hatt&hl=en&ei=YXVMTMKWBIvEsAPp68BI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=Emilie%20Demant%20Hatt&f=false|edition=Digitized Oct 1, 2008|volume=2|year=1914|publisher=American-Scandinavian Foundation|page=41}}</ref>
==Career== In 1919, Hatt was hired to be the inspector at the National Museum of Denmark's Ethnography Department, and he remained at this civil service post for ten years. This position gave him the opportunity to participate in archaeological research at numerous settlement sites in central and western [[Jutland]]. Here, he was among the first in Danish archaeology who recognized that the ancient houses were not destroyed by fire which he recognized after excavating the areas between the houses, and not just the individual house sites, which was previously the custom.<ref name="Nielsen">{{cite journal|last=Nielsen|first=Niels|year=1960|title=Gudmund Hatt. 31. oktober 1884—27. januar 1960|journal=[[Danish Journal of Geography|Geografisk Tidsskrift]]|volume=59|url=http://www.tidsskrift.dk/visning.jsp?markup=&print=no&id=69322|language=Danish}}</ref> In 1922-23, he led an archaeological expedition to the [[Virgin Islands]] and [[Santo Domingo]] in the [[Caribbean]]. From 1923, Hatt was a lecturer in cultural geography at the University of Copenhagen, becoming a full professor in 1929.
Hatt became a public figure in the late 1930s through the early 1940s with his geopolitical analyses that communicated through radio, newspaper, books and journal articles. During the [[World War II]] [[Nazi Germany|German]] [[occupation of Denmark]], Hatt joined the Danish-German reconciliation, possibly because he saw Germany as a natural and inevitable bulwark against Russian communism. After Denmark's liberation, Hatt was brought before an official court, was found to be engaged in ‘dishonourable national conduct’ during the German occupation, and was dismissed from his university chair, albeit with full pension. He became professionally more isolated, however, Hatt continued to publish more of his work in archeology.<ref name="geopoliticsandtrial" /> His last research was on the Danish [[Iron Age]] settlement in [[Fjand]].<ref name="Nielsen" /> {{Quote box | quote =''"Some ethnologists like to imagine local and independent origins for cultural phenomena. Others have a natural dislike for independent origins and prefer to search for cultural centers and the ways and roads of cultural transmission. The present writer belongs to the latter class."'' (Prof. G. Hatt) | source =<ref name="Mills">{{cite book|last=Mills|first=Philo Laos |title=Prehistoric Religion a Study in Pre-Christian Antiquity Part 1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W6TRpD5pWngC&pg=PR62&dq=Gudmund+Hatt&hl=en&ei=ZHRKTJyvB4GWsgOVquRI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Gudmund%20Hatt&f=false|year=2003 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=0-7661-3555-1|page=LXII}}</ref> | width =25% | align =right }} Hatt served on the [[Royal Danish Geographical Society]]'s council and was a member of the board of directors.<ref name="Nielsen" /> He was a member of the [[American Ethnological Society]], [[American Anthropological Association]], [[Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters]], Société Royale des Lettres de Lund, Dansk Selskab for Oldtida, La Société Royale des [[Antiquarian|Antiquaires]] du Nord, and Society des Americains de Paris.<ref name="NationalAcademies">{{cite book|last1=National Research Council (U.S.)|first1=|last2=Wenner-Gren Foundation for Anthropological Research|first2=|title=International directory of anthropologists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qD8rAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA142&lpg=PA142&dq=Gudmund+Hatt+cherokee&source=bl&ots=Ol9AYYTUpZ&sig=waNOfVyi0h9GUbdMPfcGb6_7pJc&hl=en&ei=1iVLTKa9GYKmsQO9sPVI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=Gudmund%20Hatt%20cherokee&f=false|series=Current anthropology resource series|year=1938|publisher=National Academies|page=142}}</ref> In 1915, he was awarded the [[Barnard College|Barnard]] Medal Award.<ref name="ColumbiaCollege">{{cite book|title=Catalogue|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uWfOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA497&dq=Emilie+Demant&hl=en&ei=ZnhMTM2NE4eesQPT9OhI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CEwQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=Emilie%20Demant&f=false|edition=Digitized Dec 18, 2008|year=1915|publisher=Columbia College|page=497}}</ref>
==Partial works== * [http://img.kb.dk/tidsskriftdk/pdf/gto/gto_0021-PDF/gto_0021_68328.pdf "Om Brugen af Garvemidler hos Naturfolkene" (''Geografisk Tidsskrift'', Bind 21; 1911)] (in Danish) * [http://img.kb.dk/tidsskriftdk/pdf/gto/gto_0022-PDF/gto_0022_68709.pdf "Om den kunstige Formning af Barnehovedet hos de skandinaviske Lapper" (''Geografisk Tidsskrift'', Bind 22; 1913)] (in Danish) * [http://img.kb.dk/tidsskriftdk/pdf/gto/gto_0023-PDF/gto_0023_68990.pdf "Kyst- og Indlandskultur i det arktiske" (''Geografisk Tidsskrift'', Bind 23; 1915)] (in Danish) * [http://img.kb.dk/tidsskriftdk/pdf/gto/gto_0024-PDF/gto_0024_67880.pdf "Rensdyrnomadismens Elementer" (''Geografisk Tidsskrift'', Bind 24; 1918)] (in Danish) * [http://img.kb.dk/tidsskriftdk/pdf/gto/gto_0031-PDF/gto_0031_68462.pdf "Menneskeracerne og deres Udbredelsesmuligheder" (''Geografisk Tidsskrift'', Bind 31; 1928)] (in Danish) * [http://img.kb.dk/tidsskriftdk/pdf/gto/gto_0031-PDF/gto_0031_68511.pdf "Menneskeracerne og deres Udbredelsesmuligheder (afslutning)" (''Geografisk Tidsskrift'', Bind 31; 1928)] (in Danish) * [http://img.kb.dk/tidsskriftdk/pdf/gto/gto_0032-PDF/gto_0032_68637.pdf "Begrebet „Mellemeuropa"." (''Geografisk Tidsskrift'', Bind 32; 1929)] (in Danish) * [http://img.kb.dk/tidsskriftdk/pdf/ho/ho_5rk_0001-PDF/ho_5rk_0001_75591.pdf "Oltidsagre" (''Historie/Jyske Samlinger'', Bind 5. række, 1; 1932)] (in Danish)
==References== {{Reflist|2}} * Salmon Konversationsleksikon, 2nd edition, Volume XXIV pp. 471f: ''Gudmund Hatt'' (in Danish) * Brøndsted, Johannes 1959: ''Gudmund Hatt. monument made in memory 1959'' p. 7 (in Danish) * Feilberg, CG 1959: ''Gudmund Hatt, monument made in memory 1959'' p. 9 (in Danish) * Jensen, Jørgen 1993: Birger Storgaard and Steen Hvass (eds): ''The sounds of earth ... 25 years of Archaeology in Denmark'', p. 8-13. (in Danish) * Kristensen, HK 1960: Gudmund Hatt. Kristensen, HK 1960: ''Gudmund Hatt. From Ribe 1960'' p. 145-148. (in Danish) * Larsen, Henrik Gutzon (2011) [http://vbn.aau.dk/files/65345916/Larsen_2011_The_need_and_ability_for_expansion.pdf 'The need and ability for expansion': Conceptions of living space in the small-state geopolitics of Gudmund Hatt]. ''Political Geography'', vol. 30, no. 1, pp. 38–48. * Larsen, Henrik Gutzon (2009) [http://vbn.aau.dk/files/55732133/Larsen_2009_Gudmund_Hatt.pdf Gudmund Hatt 1884-1960]. In: Hayden Lorimer & Charles W. J. Withers (eds.): ''Geographers: Biobibliographical Studies'', Vol. 28, side 17-37 (London: Continuum).
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Redirect|Ox Road|the road in Virginia in the United States|Virginia State Route 123}} [[Image:Danewerk.jpg|thumb|200px|Hærvejen crossing the [[Danevirke|Dannevirke]]]] '''Hærvejen''' ([[Danish language|Danish]], literally: ''the army road'', {{lang-de|link=no|Ochsenweg}}, literally: ''[[oxen]] way'', {{lang-nds|Ossenpadd}}, literally: oxen path), sometimes referred to in English as the '''Ox Road''',[https://books.google.com/books?id=tiQsAQAAMAAJ&q=H%C3%A6rvejen+%22army+road%22&dq=H%C3%A6rvejen+%22army+road%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yeeYUuSpOfTy7Abjw4CgCQ&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCQ ''Discovering Archaeology in Denmark''] by James Dyer (1972). Retrieved 29 Nov 2013 is the name given to an [[ancient trackway]] in Denmark and [[Schleswig-Holstein]]. The route runs from [[Viborg, Denmark|Viborg]] via [[Flensburg]] to [[Hamburg]], the territory of which it entered at Ochsenzoll ("oxen toll", "toll" in the meaning of "customs") and where it connected with other roads. It has been known by several other names throughout history, most importantly "the Cattle Road" (''Studevejen'') and "the Oxen Road" or "Ox Road" (''Oksevejen'' / ''Ochsenweg''). == History == [[Image:Povlsbro east 20040424.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Povl's Bridge from 1744]] The road runs more or less along the [[drainage divide|watershed]] of the [[Jutland]] Peninsula, known as the ''Jyske Højderyg'' (Jutland Ridge), similar to the [[ridgeway (track)|ridgeway]]s in England. By using this route one could avoid rivers, or ford them close to their origins where they were still shallow. As time went by this route was improved with paved fords, embankments and bridges. Concentrations of mounds, defensive ditches, settlements and other historic landmarks can be found along the road. While sections of it can be traced as far back as 4000 BC, newer road construction has erased many traces. Some of them show a width of up to {{convert|100|m|ft}}.''Drunter oder drüber: Elbquerungen gestern und heute'' (Brochure on the exhibition in Staatsarchiv Hamburg between 30 October till 20 December 2002 on occasion of the opening of the [[Elbe Tunnel (1975)#Dilation|4th bore of the Elbe Tunnel]]), Joachim W. Frank (ed.), Hamburg: Staatsarchiv Hamburg / Amt für Geoinformation und Vermessung, 2002, p. 8. {{ISBN|3-89907-016-X}} The use of the road declined during the Viking age,{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} as transportation by ship became more convenient. New cities were constructed along the coast instead of the road. Two of [[Denmark]]’s oldest settlements, [[Viborg, Denmark|Viborg]] and [[Jelling]] are situated along the road. In the southern, narrow part of the [[Jutland|Jutish]] peninsula the trackway followed the edge of western marshes and eastern moraine country. Near [[Haderslev]], [[Åbenrå]], [[Flensburg]], and [[Schleswig, Schleswig-Holstein|Schleswig]], it branched into western bypasses on the hills and accesses to the towns, each of them localized at the inner end of a long, narrow bay. One of the southern ends of the Ochsenweg has given its name to a suburb of [[Hamburg]]: ''Ochsenzoll'' is the locality of the ancient custom post. Part of the tracks westerly bypassed Hamburg towards [[Wedel|Wedel bei Hamburg]] or [[Blankenese]],Blankenese became a part of Hamburg in 1937 where a ferry passing the Elbe connected to [[Cranz, Hamburg|Cranz]] (then [[Prince-Archbishopric of Bremen]]Since 1648 Cranz belonged to the [[Duchy of Bremen]], but forms a part of Hamburg since 1937.).''Drunter oder drüber: Elbquerungen gestern und heute'' (Brochure on the exhibition in Staatsarchiv Hamburg between 30 October till 20 December 2002 on occasion of the opening of the [[Elbe Tunnel (1975)#Dilation|4th bore of the Elbe Tunnel]]), Joachim W. Frank (ed.), Hamburg: Staatsarchiv Hamburg / Amt für Geoinformation und Vermessung, 2002, p. 10. {{ISBN|3-89907-016-X}} An easterly bypass headed for [[Zollenspieker Ferry]] (a Hamburg-Lübeckian condominium between 1420 and 1868Since 1868 Zollespieker is a part of Hamburg.), passing the same river towards Hoopte in the then [[Principality of Lüneburg|Principality of Lunenburg]].''Drunter oder drüber: Elbquerungen gestern und heute'' (Brochure on the exhibition in Staatsarchiv Hamburg between 30 October till 20 December 2002 on occasion of the opening of the [[Elbe Tunnel (1975)#Dilation|4th bore of the Elbe Tunnel]]), Joachim W. Frank (ed.), Hamburg: Staatsarchiv Hamburg / Amt für Geoinformation und Vermessung, 2002, p. 11. {{ISBN|3-89907-016-X}} From south of the Elbe the cattle tracks continued up to [[Westphalia]]. ==Use== The road was primarily a trade road. The most important commodity was livestock (especially the eponymous [[oxen]]), but also amber, hides, honey and fur went south. Annually up to 50,000 head of cattle came along the oxen road.{{when|date=February 2014}} Metal, glass and weapons went north. In spite of the most familiar Danish name, it was seldom used for military invasions, neither northwards, nor southwards.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} Nevertheless, many defensive constructions can be found straddling the road up through Jutland. ==Today== [[Image:Hærvejen vandretureskilt.jpg|thumb|right|150px|A sign for the modern Danish Hærvejen walking route]] Today modern highways follow the route of the old road. At a few places it is still possible to see the old tracks, embankments, sheep pens and fords. Parts of it have been converted into a long-distance walking route. A popular walk known as ''Hærvejsmarchen'' takes place each year. An international cycle route has been marked from the [[Elbe]] to [[Viborg, Denmark|Viborg]]. ==Notes== ==External links== {{commons category|Hærvejen, Denmark}} *[http://www.haervej.dk/] {{Da icon}}
{{Trade route 2}} {{coord missing|Denmark}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haervejen}} [[Category:Geography of Denmark]] [[Category:Geography of Schleswig-Holstein]] [[Category:Trade routes]] [[Category:Cycleways in Denmark]] [[Category:Cycle paths in Schleswig-Holstein]] [[Category:Hiking trails in Denmark]]

== 0–9 == – [[055 Brigade]] – [[100 Classrooms program]] – [[2003 Loya jirga]]
== A == – [[Ab Band District]] – [[Ab Kamari District]] – [[Ab Khuda'i]] – [[Abaidullah]] – [[Afghan abasi|Abasi]] – [[Abd Al Rahim Abdul Rassak Janko]] – [[Abd al-Latif ibn Muhammad Taraghay Ulughbek]] – [[Abdul Ahad Mohmand]] – [[Abdul Ali Mazari]] – [[Abdul Hakim Bukhary]] – [[Abdul Haq (Afghan leader)]] – [[Abdul Jabbar Naeemi]] – [[Abdul Latif Hakimi]] – [[Abdul Malik Pahlawan]] – revision.text:
'''John Kirtland Wright''' (1891–1969) was an [[United States of America|American]] [[Geography|geographer]], notable for his [[cartography]], [[geosophy]], and study of the history of geographical thought. He was the son of classical scholar [[John Henry Wright]] and novelist [[Mary Tappan Wright]], and the brother of legal scholar and utopian novelist [[Austin Tappan Wright]]. He married Katharine McGiffert Jan. 21, 1921 in New York, N.Y. They had three children: [[Austin Wright|Austin McGiffert Wright]], Gertrude Huntington McPherson, and Mary Wolcott Toynbee.
Having completed a [[PhD]] in [[history]] at [[Harvard University]], in 1920 Wright was employed as librarian by the [[American Geographical Society]]; between the years of 1920 and 1956 he also served as an AGS editor, personal academic contributor, and eventually director. As a result of his prolific academic and professional life, three main themes have emerged in John K. Wright’s published works. These include: the overlapping of academic disciplines (mainly history) with geography, the power of the mind and the supernatural realm in creating subjectivity in geographic research, and the importance of sharing academic knowledge.<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:John Kirtland Wright.jpg|thumb|alt=Jack Wright|J.K. Wright]] -->
==Geographic Subjectivity== While at one point the discipline of geography ignored the influence of subjectivity in human and physical patterns, '''John Kirtland Wright''' brought to the forefront the significance of the mind and the imagination in affecting scientific research. Specifically, he stressed the duality of both the mind’s reality and of mental, often transcendental, images. Included in this arena of study were his interests in geographical cosmogony and cosmography, which pertained to the theological realm of the divine, “God’s invisible creation,” and the emotional bonds between people and places, which he then compared to the physical realm of land surface, climate, and [[cartography]] (Wright 1928).
==History of Geography== Wright was highly interested in the history of geography and the importance of accurate geographic archival records. He discovered and documented the influences of various religious perspectives on geography, with a very keen interest in Gothic and medieval representations that signified both divine and earthly geographic beauty (Wright 1965). In addition, he wrote prolifically on the Greek and Roman geographic influences, largely pertaining to the fifteenth- century map of the world by [[Giovanni Leardo]] (Wright,AGS,1928). This was the second oldest map that was given to the AGS in 1906, dated in the 15th century. Wright’s historic and cartographic fascination was sparked by the unusual, detailed features of the map, including a calendar encompassing the center image, and by the concept it depicted of the earth’s surface before the actual discovery of America; Leardo’s known world includes Asia, Africa, the Mediterranean, and Europe. Greek and Roman sources were used for the making of the map, specifically including Greek notions that the earth existed as a flat disk. The document lacks the evocative drawings seen in many other medieval maps that were primarily used to fill blank map space (drawings mostly of animals.) Lastly, Leardo features Jerusalem as the city center (Wright, AGS, 1928). Ultimately, Wright indicates that the blurring of the fields of history and geography has much significance, as each subject relies on the other for accuracy (Wright, Henry Holt, 1928.) After retiring as director from the American Geographical Society, Wright continued his quest for historic elucidation by writing on the history of the Society and its connection to the development of geography (Light 1950).
Wright coined the term [[choropleth map]] in 1938, although the mapping technique itself was first used by [[Charles Dupin]] in 1826. Wright cautioned against the use of choropleth maps, instead espousing the virtues of the [[dasymetric map]]. Nine years later, in 1947, Wright introduced the notion of [[geosophy]], `the study of geographical knowledge from any or all points of view. To geography what historiography is to history, it deals with the nature and expression of geographical knowledge both past and present' (Wright 1947).
==See also== *[[Geopiety]]
==Partial bibliography== * "Buildings and Parts of Cambridge Commemorated in Longfellow's Poems," in ''The Cambridge Historical Society. Publications III.'' Cambridge, Massachusetts, the Society, 1908. ([https://books.google.com/books?id=3yIQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA43&dq=%22John+Kirtland+Wright%22&lr=&as_brr=1 Google e-text]) * ''Geographical Knowledge in Western Europe from 1100 to 1250'' (thesis). 1914. * ''Aids to Geographical Research: Bibliographies and Periodicals''. New York, American Geographical Society, 1923. * ''The Geographical Lore of the Time of the Crusades; a Study in the History of Medieval Science and Tradition in Western Europe''. New York, American Geographical Society, 1925. * ''The Geographical Basis of European History''. New York, H. Holt and Company, 1928. * ''The Leardo Map of the World, 1452 or 1453, in the Collections of the American Geographical Society''. New York, American Geographical Society, 1928. * ''Sections and National Growth: an Atlas of the Historical Geography of the United States''. New York, American Geographical Society, 1932.* "The exploration of the fiord region of east Greenland: a historical outline." New York, N.Y., American Geographical Society, 1935. * ''Notes on Statistical Mapping, with Special Reference to the Mapping of Population Phenomena'' (with Loyd A. Jones, Leonard Stone and T. W. Birch). New York, American Geographical Society, 1938. * ''The European Possessions in the Caribbean area; a Compilation of Facts Concerning Their Population, Physical Geography, Resources, Industries, Trade, Government, and Strategic Importance'' (with Raye R. Platt, John C. Weaver and Johnson E. Fairchild). New York, American Geographical Society, 1941. * ''Aids to Geographical Research: Bibliographies, Periodicals, Atlases, Gazetteers and Other Reference Books'' (with Elizabeth T. Platt). 2d ed. New York, Columbia Univ. Press, 1947. * ''Geography in the Making; the American Geographical Society, 1851-1951''. New York, the Society, 1952. * ''Human Nature in Geography: Fourteen Papers, 1925-1965''. Cambridge, Harvard University Press, 1966.
==Awards== *1955 [[Gold Medal (RGS)|Founder's Gold Medal]] of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rgs.org/NR/rdonlyres/C5962519-882A-4C67-803D-0037308C756D/0/GoldMedallists18322011.pdf |title=List of Past Gold Medal Winners |publisher=Royal Geographical Society |accessdate=24 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927221002/http://www.rgs.org/NR/rdonlyres/C5962519-882A-4C67-803D-0037308C756D/0/GoldMedallists18322011.pdf |archivedate=27 September 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} *Keighren, Innes M. “Geosophy, imagination, and ''terrae incognitae'': exploring the intellectual history of John Kirtland Wright.” ''Journal of Historical Geography'' 31, no. 3 (2005): 546–62. *Light, Richard U. 1950. George Herbert Tinley Kimble, John Kirtland Wright, Gladys Mary Wrigley. Geographical Review: 40(1). *Wright, J.K. 1928. The Leardo Map of the World. New York: American Geographical Society. *Wright, J.K. 1928. Geographical Basis of European History. New York: Henry Holt & Company. *Wright, J.K. 1947. [http://www.colorado.edu/geography/giw/wright-jk/1947_ti/body.html Terrae Incognitae: The Place of Imagination in Geography], Annals of the Association of American Geographers 37: 1–15. *Wright, J.K. 1965. Geographical Lore of the Time of the Crusades. New York: Dover Publications.
==External links== *[http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/homes/ikeighre/bscresearch.html The imaginary worlds of John Kirtland Wright]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wright, John Kirtland}} [[Category:American geographers]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:Presidents of the American Association of Geographers]] [[Category:Historians of geography]]

revision.comment: [[WP:AES|←]]Created page with ''''Klooster''' is a [[Dutch language|Dutch]] [[toponymic surname]] meaning "monastery, cloister".<ref>[http://www.cbgfamilienamen.nl/nfb/detail_naam.php?gba_lcna...'
revision.text:
'''Klooster''' is a [[Dutch language|Dutch]] [[toponymic surname]] meaning "monastery, cloister".<ref>[http://www.cbgfamilienamen.nl/nfb/detail_naam.php?gba_lcnaam=klooster&gba_naam=Klooster&nfd_naam=Klooster&operator=eq&taal= Klooster] at the Database of Surnames in The Netherlands</ref> Among variant forms are ''ten Klooster'', ''Van Clooster'', ''van der Klooster'', and ''van ('t) Klooster'', each meaning "at/from (the) monastery". People with these surnames include:
*[[Dirk van 't Klooster]] (born 1976), Dutch baseball player *{{illm|Johan ten Klooster|id|Johan Frederik Engelbert ten Klooster|nl|}} (1873–1940), Dutch graphic artist and painter, father of Philip *[[Kees-Jan van der Klooster]] (born 1977), Dutch Paralympic snowboarder *[[Milton Klooster]] (born 1996), Dutch football forward, twin brother of Rodney *[[Noël Van Clooster]] (born 1943), Belgian racing cyclist *{{illm|Philip ten Klooster|id||nl|}} (1909–1969), Dutch sculptor and draughtsman, son of Johan *[[Rigard van Klooster]] (born 1989), Dutch track racing cyclist and speed skater *[[Rodney Klooster]] (born 1996), Dutch football defender, twin brother of Milton *[[Ton van Klooster]] (born 1954), Dutch freestyle swimmer *[[William Klooster]] (born 19570, Dutch ice hockey player
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Dutch-language surnames]] [[Category:Toponymic surnames]]

Munro Hamilton International Airport]] {{airport codes|YHM|}}, [[Region of Waterloo International Airport]] {{airport codes|YKF|}}, [[Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport]] {{airport codes|YTZ|}} and [[Buttonville Municipal Airport]] {{airport codes|YKZ|}}.</small>

page.title: List of colonial governors and administrators of Anguilla

revision.comment: /* Governors */ odd and inconsistent abbrev. of July
revision.text:
There have been many '''colonial governors of Anguilla'''. The official title of the position began as '''Deputy Governor of Anguilla''', which transitioned to '''Chief Magistrate of Anguilla''', and then became the current title of '''Governor of Anguilla'''.
==Deputy Governors== #[[William Watts (governor)|William Watts]] 1660-1666 #[[Abraham Howell]] 1666-1689 #[[George Leonard (governor)|George Leonard]] 1689-1735 #[[John Richardson (governor)|John Richardson]] 1735-1741 #[[Arthur Hodge (Deputy Governor of Anguilla)|Arthur Hodge]] 1741-1749 #[[John Welch (governor)|John Welch]] 1749-1750 #[[Benjamin Gumbs II]] 1750-1768 #[[Benjamin Roberts (governor)|Benjamin Roberts]] 1768-1771 #[[John Smith (Deputy Governor of Anguilla)|John Smith]] 1771-1776 #[[Benjamin Gumbs III]] 1776-1782 #[[Thomas Hodge]] 1782-1805 #[[William Richardson (governor)|William Richardson]] 1805-1829
==Chief Magistrates== #[[Richard Challenger]] 1842-1846 #[[Isidor Dyett]] 1862-1863 #[[George Alsbury]] 26 November 1863 - 28 January 1868 #[[Alexander Augustus Melfort Campbell]] (1827–1890) January 1868 - February 1869 #[[Neale Porter]] March 1869 - May 1871 #[[D.S. Lloyd]] c. 1873 #[[James L. Lake]] c. 1879-1882 #[[Edwin Baynes]] 1888 #[[N. Lockhart]] c. 1896 #[[Joseph Numa Rat]] 1897 - c. 1904 #[[G.B. Mason]] c. 1905 #[[Alan Cuthbert Burns]] 1910-1912 #W.E. Burton 1913 #[[G.I. Mendes]] c. 1913-1915 #W.E. Burton (second time) 1917-1918 #[[S.B. Jones]] 9 August 1918 - 31 May 1923 #[[J.Y. MacFadyen]] c. 1926-1933 #[[C.E.E. Stevens]] c. 1937-1938 #[[A.P. McDonald]] c. 1939-1948 #[[J.D. Maloney]] (1905-?) c. 1952-1958 #[[G.C.H. Thomas]] (1911-?) c. 1958-1962 #[[Vincent F. Byron]] 1962 - 31 May 1967 #[[Peter Adams (British governor)|Peter Adams]] July 1967 - 23 February 1968
==Governors== #[[Charles Harry Godden]] 1982–1983 #[[Alastair Turner Baillie]] 1983–1987 #[[Geoffrey Owen Whittaker]] 1987–1989 #[[Brian G.J. Canty]] 1989–1992 #[[Alan W. Shave]] 1992–1995 #[[Alan Hoole]] 1995–1996 #[[Robert Harris (Anguilla)|Robert Harris]] (born 1941) December 1996 – 27 January 2000<ref name="Anderson">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=m3gVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zOsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6695,868850&dq=anguilla+robert-harris&hl=en|title=Residents criticize launch plan|last=Anderson|first=James|date=3 May 1999|work=[[The Register-Guard]]|page=8A|accessdate=24 September 2010}}</ref> #Roger Cousins (acting) 2000 #[[Peter Johnstone (governor)|Peter Johnstone]] (born 1944) 4 February 2000 – 29 April 2004<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anguillian.com/article/articleview/1603/1/135/|title=A Big Leap Forward Protecting The Borders Of Anguilla|date=3 December 2004|work=The Anguillian|accessdate=25 September 2010}}</ref> #Mark Capes (acting) 2004 #[[Alan Huckle]] 28 May 2004 – July 2006 #Mark Capes (acting) 2006 #[[Andrew George (governor)|Andrew George]] 10 July 2006 – 11 March 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anguillian.com/article/articleview/6706/1/135/|title=Governor Gets Big Send Off "I Did It My Way"|date=13 March 2009|work=The Anguillian|accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref> #[[Stanley Reid]] (acting) 11 March 2009 – 21 April 2009 #[[Alistair Harrison]] 21 April 2009 – 18 July 2013 #[[Christina Scott]] 23 July 2013 – present
==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Anguilla.html|title=Anguilla|publisher=World Statesmen|accessdate=12 December 2011}}
==External links== * [http://gov.ai/ministry.php?id=4 Government of Anguilla] * [http://www.anguillalife.com/news/stories/local/12200.php Governor George has left the island, new Governor expected in April]
{{British dependencies governors}}

page.title: List of trolleybus routes in Bucharest

revision.text:
[[File:Bucharest Ikarus trolleybus 2.jpg|thumb|An Ikarus 415T trolley.]] This is a list of the '''15 [[trolleybus]] routes''' running in [[Bucharest]], Romania, operated by the city's public transport company, [[Societatea de Transport București|STB]] as of July 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|title = STB - Societatea de Transport Bucuresti|url = http://stbsa.ro/v_troleibuz.php|website = stbsa.ro|accessdate = 2015-07-17}}</ref> For more information about Bucharest's trolleybus network, see [[Transport in Bucharest#Trolleybuses|Trolleybuses in Bucharest]]. Routes marked with {{access icon}} use wheelchair-accessible low-floor vehicles ([[Irisbus Citelis]]) on some services, however the Ikarus 415T trolleys are more common.
There are also other routes not running due to ongoing works on the [[Bucharest Metro Line M4|M4]] and [[Bucharest Metro Line M5|M5]] metro lines.
==Routes== {| class="wikitable" border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=4 |'''Route''' |'''Start''' |'''End''' |'''Wheelchair access''' |- |61 |Master SA [[Păcii metro station|M3]] |Piata Rosetti[[Universitate metro station|M2]] |{{access icon}} |- |62 |Gara de Nord [[Gara de Nord metro station|M1/M4]] |Grup Școlar Auto |{{access icon}} |- |65 |Dridu |Sfinții Voievozi | |- |66 |Spitalul Fundeni |Vasile Pârvan |{{access icon}} |- |69 |Valea Argeșului |Baicului |{{access icon}} |- |70 |Bd. Basarabia [[Costin Georgian metro station|M1]] |Vasile Pârvan |{{access icon}} |- |73 |Turnu Măgurele |Piața Unirii | |- |74 |Bulevardul Alexandru Obregia |Piața Unirii | |- |76 |Piața Reșița |Piața Unirii | |- |79 |Bd. Basarabia [[Costin Georgian metro station|M1]] |Gara de Nord [[Gara de Nord metro station|M1/M4]] |{{access icon}} |- |85 |Gara de Nord [[Gara de Nord metro station|M1/M4]] |Baicului |{{access icon}} |- |86 |[[Arena Națională]] |Dridu |{{access icon}} |- |90 |Arena Națională |Valea Argeșului |{{access icon}} |- |91 |Depoul Alexandra |[[Piața Rosetti]] [[Universitate metro station|M2]] |{{access icon}} |- |93 |Valea Argeșului |Gara de Nord [[Gara de Nord metro station|M1/M4]] |{{access icon}} |- |96 |Depoul Alexandria |Gara de Nord [[Gara de Nord metro station|M1/M4]] |{{access icon}} |}
Temporary Suspended lines :
71 : Valea Argesului - Gara de Nord. Its place is taken by 93 (previously Gara de Nord - Valea Ialomitei) Suspended due to underground works. 90 and 91 were rerouted from Valea Ialomitei to Valea Argesului respectively to Depoul Alexandria.
92 : Vasile Parvan - Universitate - Barajul Dunarii. Suspended due to tram line works in Titan and road rehabilitation . Probably its Barajul Dunarii end of line will be changed.
97 : Strand Straulesti - Calea Grivitei - Gara de Nord - Sfintii Voievozi. Suspended due to M4 underground works. Replaced by bus line 697 from Strand Straulesti - Pod Constanta - Mezeș. From Pajura routes 65 and 86 are continuing it's from Pod Constanta onwards until Sfintii Voievozi, except 86 which goes further.
==See also== *[[Transport in Bucharest]]
{{Transport in Bucharest}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1) ([[User:Balon Greyjoy|Balon Greyjoy]])
revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=April 2014}} [[Image:Bracciano-sabatini-region-NASA-1-.jpg|thumb|250px|right|A view from the space of the Sabatini region, showing Lake Bracciano as the dark round structure. Source: Nasa Shuttle.]] [[Image:LakeBracciano.JPG|thumb|250px|Lake Bracciano.]] The '''Monti Sabatini''' is a geologic region in [[Lazio]], central [[Italy]], a remnant of intense [[volcanism]] which started ca. 600,000 years ago, mainly with [[pyroclastic]] and [[maar]] forming [[eruption]]s which continued until 100,000 years ago. The mountains are part of the Lazio's [[Anti-Apennines]]. Included between the Monti Sabatini is the [[Lake Bracciano]], which is a [[volcanotectonic depression]] formed about 3.7 Ma, and the [[Lake Martignano]]. The [[sedimentary]] base of the Sabatini complex lies buried under {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} of [[volcanic ash]] and [[rock (geology)|rock]]s. The highest point is Monte Rocca Romana (a postcaldera [[stratocone]]), at {{convert|612|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Other mountains in the area include [[Monti della Tolfa]], [[Soracte|Monte Soratte]], and more southwards, by the [[Monti Cornicolani]]. ==See also== *[[List of volcanoes in Italy]] *[[Monti Volsini]] *[[Monti Cimini]] ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051222161134/http://boris.vulcanoetna.com/SABATINI.html Sabatini Volcanic Complex]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051225110708/http://volcano.und.nodak.edu/vwdocs/volc_images/europe_west_asia/sabatini.html Sabatini, Italy]
{{Lazio}} {{coord|42|10|N|12|15|E|region:IT_type:mountain|display=title}} {{Mountains of Lazio}} [[Category:Volcanoes of Italy]] [[Category:Maars of Italy]] [[Category:Mountains of Lazio|Sabatini]] [[Category:Mountain ranges of Italy|Sabatini]] [[Category:Metropolitan City of Rome Capital]] [[Category:Geographical, historical and cultural regions of Italy]] [[Category:Falisci]]

typo
revision.text:
{{dablink|This article is about the mountain in Cyprus. For other uses, see [[Olympus (disambiguation)]]}} {{Infobox mountain | name = Mount Olympus | other_name = Chionistra | photo = Cyprus - Cave of 318 Fathers view.JPG | photo_caption = Mount Olympus in Winter | elevation_m = 1952 | elevation_ref = [http://www.summitpost.org/olympos-chionistra/150803 "Olympos (Chionistra)" on summitpost.org] Retrieved 1 October 2011 | prominence_m = 1952 | prominence_ref = [http://peaklist.org/WWlists/ultras/EuroCoreP1500m.html "Olympos" on Peaklist.org, Europe Ultra-Prominences] Retrieved 1 October 2011 | map = Cyprus |relief=1 | map_caption = Location of Mount Olympus in Cyprus | label_position = right | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]]
[[Ultra prominent peak|Ultra]] | location = [[Cyprus]] | range = [[Troodos Mountains|Troodos]] | coordinates = {{coord|34|56|11|N|32|51|48|E|type:mountain_region:CY_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | range_coordinates = | coordinates_ref = [http://www.peakbagger.com/peak.aspx?pid=10449 "Olympus" on Peakbagger.com] Retrieved 1 October 2011 | topo = | type = | age = | last_eruption = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = }} '''Olympus''', or '''Chionistra''', ({{lang-el|Όλυμπος}} or {{lang-el|Χιονίστρα}}) at {{convert|1952|m|ft}}, is the highest point in [[Cyprus]]. It is located in the [[Troodos Mountains]] of Cyprus.{{cite web|title = Country Profile: Climate|publisher = Official Website of the Embassy of the Republic of Cyprus in Washington D.C.|url = http://www.cyprusembassy.net/home/index.php?module=page&pid=11|accessdate = 2006-10-11}}. Mount Olympus peak and the "Troodos Square" fall under the territory of [[Platres]] in [[Limassol District]]. A British long range [[radar]] currently operates at Mount Olympus' peak. The Mount Olympus Ski resort consists of the Sun Valley and North Face areas. Each area has its own chairlifts and runs. Writing in the late first century BC or first century AD, the [[geographer]] [[Strabo]] reported that on one of its promontories was a temple to [[Aphrodite]] of the Heights ({{lang-el|ἀκραία}}), which women were forbidden to enter.[[Strabo]]. ''[[Geographica|Geography]]'', [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Strabo/14F*.html#6.3 XIV.6.3.] There are 4 ski slopes: * Aphrodite or Sun Valley I, Length: 150m, Level: Beginner * Hermes or Sun Valley II, Length: 150m, Level: Intermediate * Dias/Zeus or North Face I, Length: 500m, Level: Advanced * Hera or North Face II, Length: 350m, Level: Beginner ==See also== * [[List of European Ultras]] * [[List of elevation extremes by country]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mytroodos.com/ Troodos Tourism Board] *[http://www.cyprusski.com/ Cyprus Ski Federation & Club] *[http://www.skicyprus.com/webcam/ Webcam on the North side of Mount Olympus] {{Ultras of Europe}} {{Highest points of Asia}} [[Category:Ski areas and resorts in Cyprus]] [[Category:Mountains of Cyprus|Olympus]] [[Category:Temples of Aphrodite]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]] {{Cyprus-geo-stub}}
