/* Horticulture and animal farming */ grammar/usage - 'people' is a countable noun
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{cleanup rewrite|date=July 2013}} {{expert needed|Ontario tobacco belt|date=July 2013}} }}
The '''Ontario tobacco belt''' is the [[tobacco]]-growing region located in [[Norfolk County, Ontario|Norfolk County]] and eastern [[Elgin County, Ontario|Elgin County]] in [[Southwestern Ontario]], [[Canada]]. The region is close to the north shore of [[Lake Erie]], with a moderate climate and sandy, silt-loam soils that are well-suited to a wide variety of crops.<ref name="longpointbiosphere">{{cite web | url = http://longpointbiosphere.com/Publications/Wetlands/execsum/use.htm | title = Waterfowl and Wetlands of Long Point Bay and Old Norfolk County| publisher = Long Point Biosphere | date = | accessdate = 2010-11-22}}</ref>
High-value [[horticulture|horticultural]] crops thrive in this region, including 90% of all tobacco grown in Canada.<ref name="idrc">{{cite web| url = http://www.idrc.ca/en/ev-28833-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html#| title = Farmers on Tobacco Road| publisher = International Development Research Centre| date = | accessdate = 2008-11-21| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081220121439/http://www.idrc.ca/en/ev-28833-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html| archivedate = 2008-12-20| df = }}</ref> Members of Parliament elected to ridings in the Ontario tobacco belt have strong pro-tobacco policies in addition to other policies in the interest of their rural constituents.<ref name="idrc"/> Historically, the Ontario tobacco belt is composed of the rural area immediately surrounding the towns of Delhi, [[Aylmer, Ontario|Aylmer]] and [[Tillsonburg, Ontario|Tillsonburg]]. Additional tobacco farms can be found in [[Prince Edward Island]], [[Nova Scotia]], [[New Brunswick]], and near [[Joliette, Quebec|Joliette]], [[Quebec]].<ref name="idrc"/>
==History== [[United Empire Loyalist]]s introduced the tobacco crop after fleeing northwards from their established farms following the [[American Revolution]].<ref name="idrc"/> However, the first official tobacco plot wasn't planted in Norfolk County until 1920.<ref name="longpointbiosphere"/>
From the beginning of the 20th century to the 1960s, the coastal portion of the Ontario tobacco belt was threatened with [[desertification]]. Only by planting [[coniferous]] seedlings was the desertification finally stopped.<ref name="1960sglobalwarming">{{cite web| url = http://www.definingcanada.ca/2012/03/23/lets-plant-some-trees/| title = Desertification history of Southern Ontario| publisher = Defining Canada| date = | accessdate = 2012-07-25| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140506031707/http://www.definingcanada.ca/2012/03/23/lets-plant-some-trees/| archivedate = 2014-05-06| df = }}</ref> More than 25% of Norfolk County is considered to be forested.<ref>[http://www.treecanada.ca/programs/urbanforestry/cufn/Resources_Canadian/Tree%20Conservation%20By-Laws%20in%20Southern%20Ontario.pdf ''Report on Tree Conservation By-Laws in Southern Ontario''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060925044321/http://www.treecanada.ca/programs/urbanforestry/cufn/Resources_Canadian/Tree%20Conservation%20By-Laws%20in%20Southern%20Ontario.pdf |date=2006-09-25 }} at Tree Canada</ref>
The Ontario tobacco belt would experience its economic zenith during the 1950s and 1960s. During those decades, most communities in the Ontario belt (as well as their residents) were reasonably affluent from the economic gains that the tobacco farms made. The song ''Tillsonburg'' by classic [[country music]] performer [[Stompin' Tom Connors]] would capture the hard working spirit of the Ontario tobacco belt during the middle of the 20th century. A [[1979 Woodstock, Ontario tornado|devastating tornado]] that started in nearby [[Woodstock, Ontario|Woodstock]] would devastate several tobacco farms in the tobacco belt back during the late 1970s.<ref>Newark, M. (Autumn 1979). The Woodstock Tornado. ''Chinook, 1,'' 9.</ref> Recent tornadoes have not been as severe as the one that occurred in the summer of 1979, even when taking global warming into account.
While Canadian tobacco farmers (especially those in the Ontario tobacco belt) see themselves as "innocent victims" of government tobacco regulations, most of them started farming after provincial governments throughout Canada began introducing policies aimed at limiting tobacco consumption.<ref name="idrc"/> As the older farmers retire, their children will most likely seek different career paths.<ref name="idrc"/> Tobacco farms would eventually be sold to their neighbours; this has a [[domino effect]].<ref name="idrc"/> This domino effect ultimately results in fewer farmers having more acreage creating a further sense of [[economic inequality]] in the area.<ref name="idrc"/>
===Recent history=== [[File:OntarioTobaccoBeltFarmSummer2012.jpg|250px|left|thumb|Tobacco farm in Norfolk County, summer 2012.]]
The longstanding dominance of tobacco in the region has been on the wane in recent years. In 2002, politicians from the Ontario tobacco belt opposed several anti-smoking measures, causing a non-smoking group to give the [[Government of Ontario|Ontario government]] a failing grade at that time.<ref name="nosmoking"/> The tobacco belt members of [[Ontario Provincial Parliament|Provincial Parliament]] were responsible for scaling back a proposed tobacco tax from $10/carton to $5/carton.<ref name="nosmoking"/> They failed to implement a public [[smoking ban]] (until the Smoke Free Ontario law was passed in 2006).<ref name="nosmoking">{{cite web| url = http://no-smoking.org/oct02/10-17-02-2.html| title = Ontario Fails to Control Tobacco| publisher = Action on Smoking and Health| date = 2002-10-17| accessdate = 2008-11-16| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060926190639/http://no-smoking.org/oct02/10-17-02-2.html| archivedate = 2006-09-26| df = }}</ref> On August 8, 2008, tobacco [[farmer]]s in this region were given $300 million to buy out their entire tobacco quota.<ref name="ottawacitizen"/> All of the money was raised from a $1,000,000,000 fine against [[Imperial Tobacco]] and [[Rothmans, Benson & Hedges|Rothman]]'s [[Benson & Hedges]].<ref name="ottawacitizen">{{cite web| url = http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=3cee32c9-7819-4322-881f-19fc6a162b41| title = Where the buy-out money came from| publisher = Canada.com (Ottawa Citizen)| date = 2008-08-02| accessdate = 2008-11-02| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121105103145/http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=3cee32c9-7819-4322-881f-19fc6a162b41| archivedate = 2012-11-05| df = }}</ref> After receiving the money, farmers that signed the buy-out are permitted to grow any crop except for tobacco; switching to raising livestock like cattle, poultry, or pigs is completely legal under this plan.
Only about one thousand farm families still produce tobacco in the entire belt.<ref name="thestar"/> Motivation to cease tobacco farming has been accelerated by health issues and high tobacco [[tax]]es.<ref name="thestar">{{cite news | url = https://www.thestar.com/News/Ontario/article/471380| title = Ontario tobacco buy-out | publisher = The Toronto Star| date = 2008-08-01| accessdate = 2008-08-27 | first=Colin | last=Perkel}}</ref> Farmers who never agreed to the tobacco buy-out may grow as much tobacco as their farmland allows through a special tobacco growing licence that was created on the week of May 15, 2009.<ref name="betterfarming"/> Relatives of the farmers (either blood relatives or relatives through marriage) who agreed to the buy-out can still grow tobacco on the original farmer's land with a tobacco growing licence.<ref name="betterfarming"/> However, this right does not extend to the farmer himself who can still manage the farm but not own it in his name.<ref name="betterfarming">{{cite web | url = http://www.betterfarming.com/online-news/feds-change-tobacco-license-eligibility-requirements-2148| title = Relatives of Bought-Out Farmers May Still Grow Tobacco | publisher = Better Farming| date = | accessdate = 2009-05-31}}</ref> Farmers must also find a company that will buy his product; otherwise he cannot grow tobacco until next year.<ref name="betterfarming"/> Attempts by local youth sports leagues to prohibit the usage of tobacco amongst players, coaches, referees, and even spectators has been successful in a region that was once dominated by the massive profits of Big Tobacco.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.norfolkcounty.ca/media-releases/local-summer-hockey-league-goes-tobacco-free/8| title = Local summer hockey league goes tobacco-free | publisher = Norfolk County| date = | accessdate = 2011-11-07}}</ref>
Currently, Tillsonburg is under a strict bylaw aimed at reducing levels of outdoor [[Passive smoking|second-hand smoke]]. This by-law was passed on May 14, 2012 by Tillsonburg Town council; prohibiting the usage of tobacco and tobacco-related products within {{convert|9|m|ft|disp=or}} of certain buildings intended for families and/or children.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://notes.town.tillsonburg.on.ca/suiteresponse/egenda%205.0%20ga/ordinances.nsf/1db1b6453fbf13c3852562ff0065dbeb/876fc2283aa5c804852579ff005755e8?OpenDocument&Highlight=0,3596&S_PROVINCESTATEID=9&S_LEGISLATIONDOMAINID=&S_REGIONCITYID=584&sID=1434| title = Bylaw 3596 : To Prohibit Smoking In Certain Public Places Within The Town Of Tillsonburg | publisher = The Town of Tillsonburg (Ontario, Canada)| date = | accessdate = 2012-11-07}}</ref>
===Future=== By 2020, the Ontario tobacco belt will become the "Ontario [[horticulture|horticultural]] centre" because of its abundance of water. Other reasons for the sudden transformation of this region include proximity to urban markets (e.g., [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]], [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]], [[London, Ontario|London]]) and a [[sand]]y soil that favours horticultural crops.<ref name="idrc"/> European farmers will boost the average cost of farmland to $570,000 by the year 2016 due to their overspending; which would essentially give them a monopoly on the local farming business over aspiring Canadian-born farmers. An increasing number of established farmers in the area call this tax hike "unfair;" as they perceive themselves to be paying 75% less for property taxes than people who live on residential properties nearby.<ref name="europeanfarmers"/> While beef production has declined in the Ontario tobacco belt in the past 20 years, the amount of pork and chicken products that are grown in the region have increased slightly. The transition from conventional farming to [[greenhouse]]s have resulted in fewer "field" crops and a greater amount of the "hothouse" variety.<ref name="agingnorfolkfarmers">{{cite web | url = http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2012/12/12/farmers-getting-older-fewer-in-numbers| title = Farmers getting older, fewer in numbers | publisher = The Simcoe Reformer| accessdate = 2012-12-14}}</ref>
Should the sea levels rise by {{convert|60|m|ft|disp=or}}, the Ontario tobacco belt would not be affected by flooding.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://flood.firetree.net/?ll=42.8780,-80.4199&z=7&m=60| title = Impact of global warming on the Ontario Tobacco Belt | publisher = Firetree| accessdate = 2012-07-02}}</ref> However, it may be affected by droughts as a by-product of the dislocation of available fresh water and may be forced to rely on [[desalination|desalinated]] salt water piped in from the [[Eastern United States]]. Constructing the proper infrastructure to carry the water hundreds of miles away would take considerable manpower along with significant economic costs and an unprecedented level of cooperation from multiple federal, state/provincial, and municipal governments. Another possible outcome of the global climate change would bring back desertification into the [[Lake Erie]] portion of the tobacco belt. Any grasslands in the area would become brown and eventually become sand; increasing in dryness the further the piece of land is from a source of fresh water. A regional bout of famine would occur if the desertification continued to spread inland and threatened the local crops.
The price of gasoline in the Ontario tobacco belt already exceeds $1.20/litre ($4.80/US gallon); making it critical for research agencies to find a commonly affordable non-oil based fuel.<ref>[http://www.numbeo.com/cost-of-living/city_result.jsp?country=Canada&city=Simcoe%2C+ON Cost of living in Simcoe, Ontario] at Numbeo</ref> Even if ethanol fuel was economically feasible for consumers, the local climate is unable to sustain year-round temperatures of {{Convert|10|C|F|lk=on}} that is needed for optimal engine performance.<ref name="NRELE15E20">{{cite web |url=http://feerc.ornl.gov/publications/Int_blends_Rpt_1.pdf |title=Effects of Intermediate Ethanol Blends on Legacy Vehicles and Small Non-Road Engines, Report 1 |format=PDF |author1=Brian West |author2=Keith Knoll |author3=Wendy Clark |author4=Ronald Graves |author5=John Orban |author6=Steve Przesmitzki |author7=Timothy Theiss |last-author-amp=yes |publisher=[[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] and [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-10-19 |language= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217073219/http://feerc.ornl.gov/publications/Int_blends_Rpt_1.pdf |archivedate=2008-12-17 |df= }} NREL/TP-540-43543, ORNL/TM-2008/117</ref> American farmers have finally admitted to their experiments with ethanol fuel technology to being complete failures after the 2012 drought wiped out most of the corn needed to create the ethanol fuel. Wide-scale usage of ethanol fuel outside motorsports and niche motorized vehicles may never come into fruition.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/17/us/17ethanol.html?src=un&feedurl=http%3A%2F%2Fjson8.nytimes.com%2Fpages%2Fbusiness%2Fenergy-environment%2Findex.jsonp |title=Days of Promise Fade for Ethanol|author=Matthew L. Wald|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2013-03-18|accessdate=2013-03-16}}</ref>
[[Hydrogen fuel]] promises to provide an alternative fuel product for local motorized vehicle drivers once it has been accepted in urban areas where mass transit is prevalent. According to the United States Energy Information Administration, hydrogen fuel is considered to be just as safe as unleaded petroleum gasoline when it comes to unwanted explosions.<ref>U.S. Energy Information Administration. (n.d). Energy sources: hydrogen. Retrieved from: http://www.eia.gov/kids/energy.cfm?page=hydrogen_home-basics-k.cfm</ref> Fuel with hydrogen is also on par with [[compressed natural gas]];<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hydrogenandfuelcellsafety.info/2007/jun/h2cng.asp |title=Canadian Hydrogen Safety Program testing H2/CNG |work=Hydrogenandfuelcellsafety.info |date= |accessdate=2010-07-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721205150/http://www.hydrogenandfuelcellsafety.info/2007/jun/h2cng.asp |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref> which can be found in Brazil in lieu of conventional unleaded (petrol) gasoline.
As school attendance continues to decline throughout the Ontario tobacco belt, one of the solutions would be to close down [[Simcoe Composite School]] and [[Waterford District High School]] while keeping [[Valley Heights Secondary School|Valley Heights Secondary]] and [[Delhi District Secondary School]]s open. The students from the Simcoe high school and the Waterford high school would be consolidated into a giant secular high school spanning {{convert|15|acre|sqft|disp=or}} somewhere in Norfolk County. Both VHSS and DDSS have the government funding and student enrolment figures to remain open on an indefinite basis.<ref name="superschoolnorfolk">{{cite web |title=Plan B: 'Build a super school' |work=The Simcoe Reformer |url=http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2012/03/22/plan-b-build-a-super-school |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Accommodation Review Committee (ARC) - Norfolk Secondary |work=Grand Erie District School Board |url=http://www.granderie.ca/BOARD/AccommodationReviewCommitteeARCNorfolkSec.aspx |accessdate=2012-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117073319/http://www.granderie.ca/BOARD/AccommodationReviewCommitteeARCNorfolkSec.aspx |archivedate=2012-11-17 |df= }}</ref>
Reducing the number of high schools in the Ontario tobacco belt would alleviate the burden of a rapidly aging population from paying extra [[property tax]]es during their time of financial need. The buildings that currently house SCS and WDHS can either be reconfigured into housing, corporate space, possible industry sites, or even demolished at taxpayers' cost. Online education through the Internet could allow teachers to operate and to retain some form of employment; even if the building itself had to close sometime in the distant future and the school had to "operate" on a remote Internet server. All public secondary schools that currently serve students from the Ontario tobacco belt will eventually have to be converted into "Internet-only" establishments. These establishments would allow anyone between the ages of 14 and 21 with a broadband Internet connection and fluency in the [[English language]] to "attend" a high school in the Ontario tobacco belt region. The core curriculum would be taught for students in grade 9 through grade 12 in addition to Canadian culture, laws, geography, and history; helping people acquire a Canadian-style secondary school education and facilitating their way to acquiring Canadian citizenship.
===Jobs=== Most of the Ontario tobacco belt also belongs to the [[Green Energy Hub]]; an environmental region in Southern Ontario that is dedicated to creating "[[Green-collar worker|green]]" jobs through solar panels, wind turbines, and recycled rain water. Delhi, once considered to be the "heart of the Ontario tobacco belt," historically had transient adolescent workers that could find employment quickly. The local police force started to take a less tolerant stand towards these job seekers in the later years when they started to threaten the employment of local workers.<ref name="robinkers">{{cite web |title=''Picking tobacco in Delhi, Ontario'' |url=http://www.robinkers.com/tobacco.html |accessdate=2012-01-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131115144922/http://www.robinkers.com/tobacco.html |archive-date=2013-11-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
As urbanization continues to claim the [[Niagara Peninsula]], displaced farmers will come to the Ontario tobacco belt seeking acres of land to farm.<ref name="idrc"/> European farmers have bought farmland in massive amounts throughout the course of the Great Recession; fleeing the bleak prospect of farming land between airstrips in their native Europe.<ref name="europeanfarmers">{{cite web |title=''Farmers face prospect of higher taxes'' |url=http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2013/06/13/farmers-face-prospect-of-higher-taxes |accessdate=2013-06-20}}</ref> Their expertise in growing non-tobacco crops will forever change the economy of communities like Tillsonburg and Delhi.<ref name="idrc"/> Tobacco labourers will easily transition over into their new jobs in horticulture labour. Most of the jobs will involve heavy labour and no additional skills would be needed for the [[Jamaica]]n and [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[migrant worker|transient labourer]]s who "reside" in the tobacco belt region from March to November. Farm operators within the Ontario tobacco belt are 55 years old on average as of December 14, 2012 because operating a farm consists of long hours, intensive physical labour and little pay. Despite the recent economic woes, young people find greater job security working at urban office jobs than operating a rural farm in either Norfolk or Oxford County.<ref name="agingnorfolkfarmers"/>
Factories once operated in the Ontario tobacco belt; especially in the town of Simcoe. During the 42 years that it was operating, the metal-can manufacturing plant owned by The [[American Can Company]] employed many local residents. The Canadian Canning Company, which had been in operation in Simcoe since the 1870s, was a primary customer for some of the products of the American Can Plant, and was a producer of canned fruit, vegetable, and processed prepared foodstuffs, such as soup. This processing plant relied heavily on fruit and vegetables produced locally. In 1991, the Robinson Street manufacturing plants closed. The shutdown of the plants can be partially attributed to the [[Early 1990s recession|recession of the early 1990s]].<ref name="uerca">[http://www.uer.ca/locations/show.asp?locid=20330 ''American Canning Company''] historical information at UER.ca</ref>
Delhi Industries and Delhi Foundry once offered non-tobacco jobs to Delhi. They both eventually closed due to the changing Canadian economy that emphasized more on service jobs than jobs in traditional manufacturing fields. Delhi Industries lasted until the midst of the [[Great Recession|Canadian economic recession]] when it closed down on March 2010; terminating 61 Canadian jobs on a permanent basis. They once made fans and blowers for industrial operations in the region.<ref>{{cite web |title=Delhi Industries to close doors in March |url=http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2010/02/02/delhi-industries-to-close-doors-in-march |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819084920/http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2010/02/02/delhi-industries-to-close-doors-in-march |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-08-19 |accessdate=2012-11-28 }}</ref> 2600 people have officially joined the Norfolk County workforce between June 2012 and June 2013. Businesses have been expanding throughout Norfolk County again; often hiring people two at a time. Innovative business running measures are also improving the quality of life for Norfolk County residents who are members of the workforce. The economy of the [[Greater Toronto Area]] along with the rest of the world may become further interconnected with the changing economy of the Ontario tobacco belt.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2013/06/12/optimism-being-felt-in-norfolk |title=Optimism being felt in Norfolk |author=Daniel Pearce |date=June 2013 |work= |publisher=Simcoe Reformer |accessdate=June 2013}}</ref>
The well-established banks are removing their presence away from the rural communities of the Ontario tobacco belt at a fast pace. Places like Service Ontario and the Backus Heritage Conservation Area may have to shutter their doors after the departure of CIBC; leading to an almost-immediate loss of jobs within the tobacco belt.<ref>[http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2017/11/15/cibc-will-transfer-accounts-to-hagersville ''CIBC will transfer accounts to Hagersville''] at Simcoe Reformer</ref>
==Climate==
===Traditional=== The traditional climate for most of the Ontario tobacco belt has witnessed temperatures as low of {{convert|-7.8|C|F}} in January and as high as {{convert|25.6|C|F}} in July.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.almanac.com/weather/history/ON/Delhi/1960-01-01| title = Delhi, Ontario weather for January 1, 1960 | publisher = Old Farmers' Almanac| accessdate = 2012-07-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.almanac.com/weather/history/ON/Delhi/1960-07-01| title = Delhi, Ontario weather for July 1, 1960 | publisher = Old Farmers' Almanac| accessdate = 2012-07-02}}</ref> The winter of 1975 was the only unusually mild winter in the Ontario tobacco belt from 1877 to 1977.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0493(1980)108%3C1440:MFDDAA%3E2.0.CO;2| title = Maximum Freezing Degree-Days as a Winter Severity Index for the Great Lakes, 1897–1977 | publisher = American Meteorological Society | accessdate = 2017-11-12}}</ref>
Even the traditional climate was considered to be inhospitable for some as the threat of [[desertification]] raged on from the early 20th century through the 1960s. Only by planting [[coniferous]] seedlings did the Ontario tobacco belt started to become a more friendly climate for tobacco production.<ref name="1960sglobalwarming"/>
Historically, the hottest temperatures in the Ontario tobacco belt were recorded on July 9, 1936 with [[Delhi, Ontario|Delhi]] registering temperatures up to {{convert|40.6|C|F|disp=or}}.<ref>[[Environment Canada]] [http://www.climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climate_normals/results_e.html?stnID=4624&lang=e&dCode=1&province=ONT&provBut=&month1=0&month2=12 Canadian Climate Normals 1971-2000], accessed 18 March 2012</ref>
===Modern=== An overnight frost in the early fall of 1999 damaged the unharvested crops of one hundred local tobacco farms; Norfolk County, Brant County, and Oxford County were affected in the disaster.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/story/1999/09/22/frost220999.html| title = Frost Caused Damage in Tobacco Belt | publisher = CBC News| date = 1999-09-22| accessdate = 2008-11-17}}</ref> An official reading of {{convert|35.7|C|F|disp=or}} from the Delhi weather station recorded on July 7, 2012 has seen rising temperatures become a nearly unstoppable trend in the Ontario tobacco belt.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.almanac.com/weather/history/ON/Delhi/2012-07-07| title = Delhi, Ontario weather for July 7, 2012 | publisher = Old Farmers' Almanac| date = 2012-07-07| accessdate = 2012-07-15}}</ref>
When temperatures in the Ontario tobacco belt manage to reach a high of beyond {{convert|30|C|F|disp=or}}, overall crop yields can be reduced as much as 1% per day; leading to potential crop failures months ahead of the proper harvest schedule.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.uoguelph.ca/plant/treefruit/documents/2011BookCelbratingThePast.pdf| title = Celebrating the Past | publisher = University of Guelph| accessdate = 2013-06-07}}</ref> The number of days that the Ontario tobacco belt spends in temperatures in excess of {{convert|30|C|F|disp=or}} are rising due to shifting weather patterns. Within the next 20 years, the industrial character of Norfolk, Brant and Oxford counties might have to change in order to adapt to the difficulties that future farmers will face concerning the well-being of their crops.
However, with the summer temperatures of 2009 having been the [[Year Without a Summer|coldest since 1816]],<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=en&n=714D9AAE-1&news=7DDF8AF2-FE36-439D-A474-4FD32F86C148| title = Ontario Weather Review - July 2009| publisher = Environment Canada| date = 2009-09-01| accessdate = 2011-10-27| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121203043636/http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=714D9AAE-1&news=7DDF8AF2-FE36-439D-A474-4FD32F86C148| archivedate = 2012-12-03| df = }}</ref> the number of successful tobacco and food crops were fewer and more expensive because of fears of an early frost that never quite surfaced in 2009. The same effect was felt months after the [[2009 North American Christmas blizzard|severe December 22–28 blizzard]] with the subsequent blizzards on [[February 5–6, 2010 North American blizzard|February 5–6, 2010]] and on [[February 25–27, 2010 North American blizzard|February 25–27]] of that same year. There were two outbreaks of blizzards that occurred in this area between [[January 25–27, 2011 North American blizzard|January 25]] and [[January 31 – February 2, 2011 North American blizzard|February 2, 2011]]. After the start of 2012, the effects of the March 2012 North American heat wave has rendered virtually all snowfall in this area non-existent for the first time since the winter of 1994-95.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=714D9AAE-1&news=63AF4245-1A79-4D63-A54C-64AEC7DDE8F4| title = Ontario Weather Review - February 2012 | publisher = Environment Canada| date = 2012-03-19| accessdate = 2012-06-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=714D9AAE-1&news=F9FD4ABF-A8CC-4475-9E0F-7E8F22F152A2| title = Ontario Weather Review - January 2012 | publisher = Environment Canada| date = 2012-02-28| accessdate = 2012-06-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ec.gc.ca/default.asp?lang=En&n=714D9AAE-1&news=1B566320-3346-46D9-A1E9-B422CB614ED6| title = Ontario Weather Review - March 2012 | publisher = Environment Canada| date = 2012-05-24| accessdate = 2012-06-18}}</ref> The heat wave has also shattered all of the temperature records throughout the Ontario tobacco belt along with the rest of Southern Canada and parts of North America.<ref name="NASA Earth Observatory">{{cite journal |title=Historic Heat in North America Turns Winter to Summer |url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=77465 |date=21 March 2012| accessdate=23 March 2012| newspaper=NASA Earth Observatory}}</ref> This heat wave has extended itself into the [[Summer 2012 North American heat wave|summer months]]. During August 2012, only parts of [[South America]] and [[Northern Australia]] experienced temperatures that were cooler than usual.<ref>[http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=78869 ''Mapping the Hot Summer''] at Earth Observatory (NASA)</ref> The heat wave officially ended in early November 2012 when local temperatures plunged below {{convert|10|C|F|disp=or}}.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.almanac.com/weather/history/ON/Delhi/2012-11-01| title = Delhi, Ontario weather for November 1, 2012 | publisher = Old Farmers' Almanac| accessdate = 2012-11-07}}</ref>
Between December 2012 and April 2013, temperatures managed to return to normal seasonal levels for the Ontario tobacco belt along with most of Ontario.<ref>{{cite web |title=Temperatures predictions for December 2012-April 2013 |url=http://vortex.accuweather.com/adc2004/pub/includes/columns/abrams/2012/590x375_07101134_jul9b.png |accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> While May and June 2013 has seen temperatures that were slightly above normal, July 2013 has seen the return of extremely warm temperatures. Temperatures did not return to normal seasonal patterns until the middle of October 2013. However, the [[2013–14 North American cold wave]] victimized Norfolk County from January to mid-April 2014 with unusually frequent cases of blizzards and snowstorms. An expected heat wave for the summer months of 2014 never emerged, meaning that temperatures in the Ontario tobacco belt have remained close to normal.
The months of April and May 2015 saw temperatures that went directly from being unseasonably cold to unseasonably warm and back to unseasonably cold without any moderate weather in between. Cloudy days with high winds dominate the colder days while the unseasonably warm weather brought about threats of thunderstorms during the evening hours.<ref>[http://www.accuweather.com/en/ca/simcoe/n3y/april-weather/54995 Weather information for Simcoe, Ontario - April 2015]</ref><ref>[http://www.accuweather.com/en/ca/simcoe/n3y/month/54995?monyr=5/01/2015 Weather information for Simcoe, Ontario - May 2015]</ref>
The temperatures from June to early September 2015 were seen as unusually warm and/or muggy. Thunderstorms and essential rainfall was deemed to be few and far in-between; with normal seasonal temperatures returning around late September of that year.
The winter of 2016 experienced a lack of snowfall not seen since the winter of 2012. While the summer months of 2016 were as equally dry and hot as the summer of 2015, it was considerably more windy in 2016 than it was in 2015. The dry summer affected everything from trees to wildlife to the water levels for [[Lake Erie]]. Rain finally returned around October and November 2016 when the cold front needed to produce precipitation was finally created in order to fight the dominant warm front.
==Replacements for tobacco==
===Horticulture and animal farming=== Compared to 1998, tobacco farming is down by 60% and falling.<ref name="smokypolitics"/> It is possible that this tobacco industry will never recover and disappear forever.<ref name="smokypolitics">{{cite web | url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/politicalbytes/2008/08/tobacco_strategy.html| title = Political Bites: Smoky politics | publisher = CBC News| date = | accessdate = 2008-08-27}}</ref> Calls to action by local residents to diversify the tobacco belt into other industries have been slow in being answered by Norfolk County council. Diversification into several different types of products could help the region absorb the ups and downs of a changing economy. The winter hardiness and soil requirements of lavender are equivalent to that of tobacco; meaning that an "Ontario horticultural belt" could see the economy revolve around lavender plants rather than tobacco plants.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.norfolknews.ca/news-story/4404488-a-tale-of-two-tobacco-farms/| title = A tale of two tobacco farms | publisher = Norfolk News| date = | accessdate = 2014-07-29}}</ref>
Tobacco farmers in this region have to deal with the same issues that haunt [[Europe]]an tobacco farmers; farmers are told to grow different crops or go out of business.<ref name="europetobacco"/> However, it is difficult to adjust to the changing supply and demand when most farmers are in heavy debt.<ref name="europetobacco">{{cite web | url = http://www.savetobaccogrowers.com/index.php?action=article&numero=22| title = Situation of tobacco farmers (from Europe's perspective) | publisher = Save Tobacco Growers| date = 2008-08-20| accessdate = 2008-11-02}}</ref> The economic fallout from the [[Great Recession|Canadian economic recession]] also played in role in declining tobacco sales and farmers going deeper into debt. There are also good opportunities for [[winery|wineries]], [[peanut]] farms, [[poultry]] farms, and [[apiary|apiaries]] to fill the void that tobacco leaves behind economically.<ref name="ogov"/> Most of these alternative crops are either grown or raised in Norfolk County; that is where the cash crush of a declining tobacco market is affecting the most people.<ref name="ogov">{{cite web | url = http://ogov.newswire.ca/ontario/GONE/2008/06/05/c7463.html?lmatch=&lang=_e.html| title = Government of Ontario (Canada) news | publisher = Government of Ontario (Canada)| date = 2008-06-05| accessdate = 2008-11-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
===Wind generators=== [[Wind generator]]s have been used extensively in the Port Rowan area and in the southwestern part of Norfolk County (particularly near Lake Erie).<ref name="norcountywindturb">{{cite web| url = http://www.norfolkcounty.ca/images/PDF/PlanningEcDev/Mapping/Wind%20Turbines.pdf| title = Lakeshore Wind Turbines| accessdate = 2010-04-11}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Port Rowan has seen some wind generators installed in the northern end of their community near their active adult community; but were dismantled after the local people starting protesting. Most of them are seen near the communities of Clear Creek, Jacksonburg, Houghton Centre, and Hemlock.<ref name="norcountywindturb"/> [[Port Dover, Ontario|Port Dover]] (on the easternmost part of the Ontario tobacco belt) has been declared to be the site of future wind generators.<ref name="portdoverwindgenerators">The Simcoe Reformer - January 19, 2011</ref> Norfolk County has banned the placement of new wind turbines after becoming a "willing host" for them back in 2003. One of the council members were worried about Norfolk County becoming "industrialized" and "unnatural." Many leaders in Norfolk County envision the surrounding area as being an agricultural hub for Southern Ontario even by the middle of the 22nd century.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.simcoereformer.ca/2013/05/14/norfolk-seeks-end-to-turbine-development| title = Norfolk Seeks End to Turbine Development| accessdate = 2013-05-15}}</ref>
By harvesting the local [[wind energy]], it is assumed that electricity could be created closer to home without using fossil fuels and without polluting the atmosphere or the water that people need to live. However, one of the side effects has been the unexplained killing of the [[bald eagle]] species that is being rehabilitated in the area.<ref name="deadbirds">{{cite web| url = http://windconcernsontario.wordpress.com/2010/04/06/bald-eagle-killed-by-wind-turbine-in-norfolk-county-ontario/| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100409185104/http://windconcernsontario.wordpress.com/2010/04/06/bald-eagle-killed-by-wind-turbine-in-norfolk-county-ontario/| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 2010-04-09| title = Wind Concerns Ontario (Wordpress)| date = 2010-04-06| accessdate = 2010-04-11}}</ref> Wind energy supporters have stated in the past that fossil fuel-based [[power plant]]s affect the birds in a less humane manner.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{Cite journal| first1 = B. K.| title = Contextualizing avian mortality: A preliminary appraisal of bird and bat fatalities from wind, fossil-fuel, and nuclear electricity| journal = Energy Policy| last1 = Sovacool| volume = 37| issue = 6| pages = 2241–2248| year = 2009| doi = 10.1016/j.enpol.2009.02.011| authorlink1 = Benjamin K. Sovacool}}</ref>
The cost of the wind generator devices (approximately $4 million [[Canadian dollar|CAD]] per unit) has caused the short-term price of [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric energy]] to increase as it became more expensive to deliver the needed energy due to complications with the electricity grid.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://ottawacitizen.com/entertainment/Hydro+prices+going+like+rocket/3428382/story.html | title = Hydro prices going like rocket | publisher = Ottawa Citizen | accessdate = 2011-11-12}}</ref> While rent has remained very cheap (approximately 870 Canadian dollars a month) by global standards in Brantford, the rising cost of electricity has made the typical restaurant meal in that city to be very expensive (with the cost of a meal between 10.50 Canadian dollars a person for lunch to 67.50 Canadian dollars a person for an elegant dinner); particularly when compared to other communities within Southern Ontario.<ref>[http://www.numbeo.com/cost-of-living/city_result.jsp?country=Canada&city=Brantford Cost of living in Brantford, Canada] at Numbeo</ref>
The conventional Ontario electricity grid had become dependent on fossil fuels,<ref name="electricityinontario">{{cite web | url = http://www.uoguelph.ca/~whulet/OGN/Vol1Issue1/Glen_Estill.htm | title = Electricity in Ontario | publisher = University of Guelph | accessdate = 2011-11-12}}</ref> [[transformer]]s,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ontarioenergyboard.ca/OEB/Consumers/OEB+and+You/Ontario+Energy+Sector | title = The Electricity Sector | publisher = Ontario Energy Board | accessdate = 2011-11-12}}</ref> and [[Nuclear power|nuclear energy]] for decades before the wind turbines started appearing.<ref name="electricityinontario"/> However, these concerns are negated by wind energy proponents who say that the turbines could lead to electricity price reductions through lower natural gas prices (due to the reductions in natural gas demand).<ref>Wiser, R., Bolinger, M. (2007). “Can deployment of renewable energy put downward pressure on natural gas prices?” Energy Policy, Volume 35, pp.295-306.</ref>
The use of [[fossil fuel]]s is becoming less frequent amongst both rural and urban people as it becomes more expensive.<ref name="saudiarabia2037">{{cite web| url = http://www.fortunecity.com/boozers/bridge/632/article39.html| title = Saudi Arabia in the year 2037 - also deals with developed countries having alternative fuels| accessdate = 2010-11-17| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20010723120601/http://www.fortunecity.com/boozers/bridge/632/article39.html| archivedate = 2001-07-23| df = }}</ref> Dwindling oil supplies (that will be completely diminished by 2057<ref>{{cite web | title = Tapped Out | url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2008/06/world-oil/roberts-text | accessdate = 2008-06-18 }}</ref>) are leaving humanity little choice but to invest in wind and solar generators. Worldwide protests against the development of new [[oil field]]s are also bringing up the price of fossil fuels.<ref>Alaska Inter-Tribal Council. [http://aitc.org/node/22 "NCAI Resolution #BIS-02-056."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605080806/http://aitc.org/node/22 |date=2010-06-05 }} 26 May 2005. Retrieved on 2008-8-01.</ref><ref>[http://www.indianz.com/News/2005/007098.asp "Gwich'in leader blasts Senate vote on ANWR drilling."] Indianz.com 18 Mar. 2005. Retrieved on 2008-8-01.</ref> Alternative fuels (like [[wind energy]] from the nearby [[Erie Shores Wind Farm]] and all [[solar energy]] projects done in this area in the future) will eventually relegate the use of fossil fuels to the [[Middle East]] and to [[developing country|developing countries]].<ref name="saudiarabia2037"/> These alternatives will be cheaper and cleaner than the energy forms that rely on fossil fuels.<ref name="saudiarabia2037"/> The increasingly frequent use of alternative clean fuels (such as natural gas, wind, and solar) could help control pollution from fossil fuel use, and mitigate [[global warming]].<ref name=Hansen2007>{{cite journal | url = http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/testimony_26april2007.pdf | author = Hansen, J. | title = Dangerous Human-Made Interference with Climate | journal = Testimony to Select Committee on Energy Independence and Global Warming, United States House of Representatives | volume = 26 | year = 2007 | accessdate =2 July 2008 |format=PDF}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|3}}
{{Norfolk County, Ontario}}
{{Coord|42.78822|-80.433998|display=title}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ontario Tobacco Belt}} [[Category:Geography of Elgin County]] [[Category:Geography of Norfolk County, Ontario]] [[Category:Geography of Ontario]] [[Category:History of Ontario by location]] [[Category:Tobacco in Canada]] [[Category:Agriculture in Canada]] [[Category:Geographic regions of Ontario]] [[Category:Belt regions]]

page.title: Orders, decorations, and medals of the Republic of China

revision.comment: image->file; tidy
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} This is a '''list of orders, decorations and medals of the Republic of China''', usually known as '''[[Taiwan]]''' after 1949. This list is sorted in order of precedence of the highest grade of each award on a full military dress. The Honour Sabre is a special case and is listed separately under ''Military orders'', as per its official classification by the [[Ministry of National Defense of the Republic of China|Ministry of National Defense]]. ==Military orders== {| class="wikitable" ! width="23%" | Name ! width="18%" | Grades ! Awarded for ! width="144px" | Ribbon bar ! width="10%" | InstitutedDate of institution given is of the first incarnation of the award. Changes since then of the design and/or grades are noted separately. Dates of institution obtained from Ministry of National Defense and Office of the President, see ''References'' below. |- |
'''[[Order of National Glory]]'''
國光勳章
|1 (Grand Cordon)The ''Order of National Glory'' and ''Order of Blue Sky and White Sun'' had a [[Rosette (decoration)|Rosette]] device until 19 November 1980 |Distinguished contributions to national defense ![[File:Order of National Glory with Grand Cordon ribbon.png]] |8 November 1937 |- |
'''[[Order of Blue Sky and White Sun]]'''
青天白日勳章
|1 (Grand Cordon) |Outstanding contributions to national defense ![[File:Order of Blue Sky and White Sun with Grand Cordon ribbon.png]] |15 May 1929 |- | rowspan=9 |
'''[[Order of the Sacred Tripod]]'''
寶鼎勳章
|1 (Special Grand Cordon) | rowspan=9 | Repelling foreign invasion or quelling internal unrest ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Special Grand Cordon ribbon.png]] | rowspan=9 | 15 May 1929 |- |2 (Grand Cordon) ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Grand Cordon ribbon.png]] |- |3 (Red Grand Cordon)The ''Order of Precious Tripod, 3rd Class'' and ''Order of Resplendent Banner, 3rd Class'' had no device prior to 19 November 1980 ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Red Grand Cordon ribbon.png]] |- |4 (Special Cravat)The ''Special Cravat'' and ''Cravat'' grades are [[neck order]]s. ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Special Cravat ribbon.png]] |- |5 (Cravat) ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Cravat ribbon.png]] |- |6 (Special Rosette) ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Special Rosette ribbon.png]] |- |7 (Rosette) ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Rosette ribbon.png]] |- |8 (Special Ribbon) ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Special Ribbon ribbon.png]] |- |9 (Ribbon) ![[File:Order of Precious Tripod with Ribbon ribbon.png]] |- |
'''[[Order of Loyalty and Valour]]'''
忠勇勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |Bravery in combat ![[File:Order of Loyalty and Valour ribbon.png]] |23 September 1944 |- | rowspan=9 |
'''[[Order of the Cloud and Banner]]'''
雲麾勳章
|1 (Special Grand Cordon) | rowspan=9 | Contributions to the nation or quelling internal unrest ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Special Grand Cordon ribbon.png]] | rowspan=9 | 15 June 1935 |- |2 (Grand Cordon) ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Grand Cordon ribbon.png]] |- |3 (Yellow Grand Cordon) ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Yellow Grand Cordon ribbon.png]] |- |4 (Special Cravat) ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Special Cravat ribbon.png]] |- |5 (Cravat) ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Cravat ribbon.png]] |- |6 (Special Rosette) ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Special Rosette ribbon.png]] |- |7 (Rosette) ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Rosette ribbon.png]] |- |8 (Special Ribbon) ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Special Ribbon ribbon.png]] |- |9 (Ribbon) ![[File:Order of Resplendent Banner with Ribbon ribbon.png]] |- |
'''[[Order of Loyalty and Diligence]]'''
忠勤勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |10 years' service in the military and meeting academic criteria ![[File:Order of Loyalty and Diligence ribbon.png]] |23 September 1944 |- |
'''Order of Grand Community'''
大同勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |Significant contributions to the Air Force in battle or in its construction ![[File:Order of Grand Community ribbon.png]] |14 June 1945 |- |
'''Order of Cosmic Diagram'''
河圖勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |Bravery in combat with 1,800 hours of flight time or 600 missions in the Air Force ![[File:Order of Cosmic Diagram ribbon.png]] |14 June 1945 |- |
'''Order of Book of Nature'''
洛書勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |Bravery in combat with 1,500 hours of flight time or 500 missions in the Air Force ![[File:Order of Book of Nature ribbon.png]] |14 June 1945 |- |
'''Order of Sublime Commencement'''
乾元勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |Bravery in combat with 1,200 hours of flight time or 400 missions in the Air Force ![[File:Order of Sublime Commencement ribbon.png]] |14 June 1945 |- |rowspan=3 |
''' Order of Renaissance and Honour'''
復興榮譽勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |9 kills, 900 hours of flight time or 300 missions in the Air Force ![[File:Order of Renaissance and Honour, First Class ribbon.png]] | rowspan=3 | 3 December 1937 |- |2 (Ribbon) |6 kills, 750 hours of flight time or 250 missions in the Air Force ![[File:Order of Renaissance and Honour, Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |3 (Ribbon) |3 kills, 600 hours of flight time or 200 missions in the Air Force ![[File:Order of Renaissance and Honour, Third Class ribbon.png]] |- |
'''Order of Victory of Resistance against Aggression'''
抗戰勝利勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |Contributions to the Chinese nation during the Second Sino-Japanese War ![[File:Order of Victory of Resistance against Aggression ribbon.png]] |10 October 1945 |- |
'''Order in Commemoration of the Tenth Anniversary of the Oath-taking of the National Revolutionary Army'''
國民革命軍誓師十週年紀念勳章
|1 (Ribbon) |Officers who hold the rank of [[Major General]] or above and who have commanded a [[Division (military)|Division]]-level unit or above, and took the oath to [[Northern Expedition (1926–1927)|unify the country]] in 1926, [[Guangdong]]. ![[File:Order in Commemoration of the Tenth Anniversary of the Oath-taking of the National Revolutionary Army ribbon.png]] |8 July 1936 |} {| class="wikitable" ! width="23%" | Name ! width="18%" | GradesPrior to 1 August 1935 the ''Honour Sabre'' was presented in nine grades, from 9 stars to 1 star, respectively. On the current design, lions are carved in golden relief on the [[scabbard]] and [[hilt]]. ! Awarded for ! width="10%" | Instituted |- |rowspan=3 |
'''[[Honour Sabre of the Awakened Lion]]'''
醒獅勳刀
|1 (9 Lions, yellow tassel) |rowspan=3 | Already-highly decorated officers who are deserving of more commendation |rowspan=3 | 23 November 1931 |- |2 (7 Lions, blue tassel) |- |3 (5 Lions, red tassel) |} ==Military medals== ===General Armed Forces medals=== {| class="wikitable" ! width="23%" | Name ! width="18%" | GradesFor all medals with A and B grades, A grade medals are awarded to officers holding the rank of [[Major (rank)|Major]] or above, and B grade medals are awarded to soldiers of ranks including and below [[Captain (land)|Captain]]. ! Awarded for ! width="144px" | Ribbon bar ! width="10%" | Instituted |- |rowspan=4 |
'''Medal of the Armed Forces'''First time recipients receive the Second Class of the medal, second time recipients receive the First Class of the medal, and further decorations are to be denoted with [[award star]]s.
陸海空軍獎章
|A-1 (Ribbon) |rowspan=4 | Outstanding performance or exhibiting special technical skills ![[File:Medal of the Armed Forces, A-First Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=4 | 15 August 1929 |- |A-2 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Armed Forces, A-Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |B-1 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Armed Forces, B-First Class ribbon.png]] |- |B-2 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Armed Forces, B-Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |rowspan=4 |
'''Medal of the Brilliant Light'''
光華獎章
|A-1 (Ribbon) |rowspan=4 | Outstanding performance or exhibiting special technical skills ![[File:Medal of the Brilliant Light, A-First Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=4 | 7 September 1937 |- |A-2 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Brilliant Light, A-Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |B-1 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Brilliant Light, B-First Class ribbon.png]] |- |B-2 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Brilliant Light, B-Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |rowspan=4 |
'''Medal of Victorious Garrison'''
干城獎章
|A-1 (Ribbon) |rowspan=4 | Outstanding performance or exhibiting special technical skills ![[File:Medal of Victorious Garrison, A-First Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=4 | 7 September 1937 |- |A-2 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of Victorious Garrison, A-Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |B-1 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of Victorious Garrison, B-First Class ribbon.png]] |- |B-2 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of Victorious Garrison, B-Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |
'''Medal of Loyalty and Integrity'''
忠貞獎章
|1 (Ribbon and Stars)First time recipients receive 1 silver star; Second time recipients 2 silver stars; Third time 3 silver stars; Beyond 3, every 3 silver stars is exchanged for a gold star. |Soldiers who are wounded in combat. ![[File:Medal of Loyalty and Integrity ribbon.png]] |Dec 1945 |- |rowspan=4 |
'''Medal of the Spirit of Chu'''
莒光獎章
|A-1 (Ribbon) |rowspan=4 |Significant contributions to the Armed Forces in the areas of technology, logistics and finance. ![[File:Medal of the Spirit of Chu, A-First Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=4 | 12 June 1971 |- |A-2 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Spirit of Chu, A-Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |B-1 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Spirit of Chu, B-First Class ribbon.png]] |- |B-2 (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of the Spirit of Chu, B-Second Class ribbon.png]] |- |
'''Medal of Victory of Resistance against Aggression'''
抗戰勝利獎章
|1 (Ribbon) |Contributions during the Second Sino-Japanese War. ![[File:Medal of Victory of Resistance against Aggression ribbon.png]] |8 January 1946 |- |} ===Army medals=== {| class="wikitable" ! width="23%" | Name ! width="18%" | Grades ! Awarded for ! width="144px" | Ribbon bar ! width="10%" | Instituted |- |rowspan=2 |
'''Medal of Army Brilliance'''
陸光獎章
|A (Ribbon) |rowspan=2 | Being victorious in combat, proactively render assistance to friendly troops, and other significant contributions. ![[File:Medal of Army Brilliance, A Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=2 | 5 May 1958 |- |B (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of Army Brilliance, B Class ribbon.png]] |- |rowspan=2 |
'''Medal of Outstanding Service'''
金甌獎章
|A (Ribbon) |rowspan=2 | Significant contributions such as destroying enemy forces, securing the border, preventing rebellions or participation in military projects ![[File:Medal of Outstanding Service, A Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=2 | 5 May 1958 |- |B (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of Outstanding Service, B Class ribbon.png]] |- |rowspan=2 |
'''Medal of Bravery'''
虎賁獎章
|A (Ribbon) |rowspan=2 | Significant contributions during battle, such as destroying enemy fortifications, routing enemy reinforcements, and assisting the main force in combat. ![[File:Medal of Bravery, A Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=2 | 5 May 1958 |- |B (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of Bravery, B Class ribbon.png]] |- |rowspan=2 |
'''Medal of Outstanding Staff'''
弼亮獎章
|A (Ribbon) |rowspan=2 | Significant contributions in research. ![[File:Medal of Outstanding Staff, A Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=2 | 5 May 1958 |- |B (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of Outstanding Staff, B Class ribbon.png]] |- |rowspan=2 |
'''Medal of Army Achievement'''
景風獎章
|A (Ribbon) |rowspan=2 | Being corruption-free and highly productive. ![[File:Medal of Army Achievement, A Class ribbon.png]] |rowspan=2 | 5 May 1958 |- |B (Ribbon) ![[File:Medal of Army Achievement, B Class ribbon.png]] |- |
'''Medal of Excellent Efficiency'''
寶星獎章
|1-9 (Ribbon and Stars) |1 Star for every 3 years of service and meeting academic requirements, up to 9 Stars. ![[File:Medal of Excellent Efficiency ribbon.png]] |5 May 1958 |} ===Navy medals=== {| class="wikitable" ! width="23%" | Name ! width="18%" | Grades ! Awarded for ! width="144px" | Ribbon bar ! width="10%" | Instituted |- |
'''Medal of Naval Brilliance'''
海光獎章
|1 (Ribbon) |Contributions in command or combat, for conspicuous gallantry and those wounded on duty. ![[File:Medal of Naval Brilliance ribbon.png]] |19 July 1951 |- |
'''Medal of Naval Achievement'''
海功獎章
|1 (Ribbon) |Contributions in combat. ![[File:Medal of Naval Achievement ribbon.png]] |19 July 1951 |- |
'''Medal of Naval Merit'''
海勳獎章
|1 (Ribbon) |Contributions to military strategy, military literature and technological research. ![[File:Medal of Naval Merit ribbon.png]] |19 July 1951 |- |
'''Medal of Naval Distinguished Service'''
海績獎章
|1 (Ribbon) |Meeting labour service requirements. ![[File:Medal of Naval Distinguished Service ribbon.png]] |19 July 1951 |- |
'''Medal of Naval Disposition'''
海風獎章

Awarded for ! width="144px" | Ribbon bar ! width="10%" | Instituted |- |
'''[[Order of Brilliant Jade]]'''
采玉勳章
|1 (Grand Cordon) |Foreign heads of state. ![[File:Order of Brilliant Jade (Taiwan) - ribbon bar.gif|120px]] |2 December 1933 |- |
'''[[Order of Dr. Sun Yat-Sen]]'''
中山勳章
|1 (Grand Cordon) |Contributions to national development. !NA |12 February 1941 |- |
'''[[Order of Chiang Chung-Cheng]]'''
中正勳章
|1 (Grand Cordon) |1. Implementation of the [[Three Principles of the People]]
2. National development
3. Revival of Chinese culture
4. Implementation of democratic reforms !NA |11 January 1980 |- | rowspan=9 |
'''[[Order of Propitious Clouds]]'''
卿雲勳章
|1 (Special Grand Cordon) | rowspan=9 | Contributions to national and societal development. ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 1Class BAR.svg|120px]] |rowspan=9 | 12 February 1941 |- |2 (Grand Cordon) ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 2Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |3 (Green Grand Cordon) ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 3Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |4 (Special Cravat) ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 4Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |5 (Cravat) ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 5Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |6 (Special Rosette) ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 6Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |7 (Rosette) ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 7Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |8 (Special Ribbon) ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 8Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |9 (Ribbon) ![[File:TWN Order of Propitious Clouds 9Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- | rowspan=9 |
'''[[Order of Brilliant Star]]'''
景星勳章
|1 (Special Grand Cordon) | rowspan=9 | Contributions to national and societal development. ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 1Class BAR.svg|120px]] |rowspan=9 | 12 February 1941 |- |2 (Grand Cordon) ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 2Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |3 (Green Grand Cordon) ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 3Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |4 (Special Cravat) ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 4Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |5 (Cravat) ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 5Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |6 (Special Rosette) ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 6Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |7 (Rosette) ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 7Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |8 (Special Ribbon) ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 8Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |9 (Ribbon) ![[File:TWN Order of Brilliant Star 9Class BAR.svg|120px]] |- |
'''Public Servants' Service Medal'''
|NA |NA !NA |NA |} ==Defunct orders== Prior to the modern system, the Republican government established numerous orders that are now defunct. ===Nanjing Era=== After the founding of the Republic, the Nanjing Provisional Government established the following orders in 1912: * Order of the Nine Tripods (九鼎勳章): 9 grades, a military decoration. * Order of Tiger and Bear (虎羆勳章): 9 grades, a military decoration. * Order of the Waking Lion (醒獅勳章): 9 grades, mixed military and civilian decoration. ===Beiyang Era=== The Beijing government re-established the honour system with the following orders: * The Grand Order (大勳章): for ceremonial use by the Head of State. * Badge of Mongolian, Hui and Tibetan Nobility (蒙回藏爵章): 5 grades, awarded to lords of Mongolia, Xinjiang and Tibet who bore [[Qing dynasty]] princely and ducal titles. The grades of this order correspond to Qing's princely ranks. * Order of Rank and Merit (勳位章): 5 grades, highest general decoration. * Order of Precious Brilliant Golden Grain (寶光嘉禾勳章): 5 grades and 6 classes, awarded only to high-level officials. * Order of the Golden Grain (嘉禾勳章): 9 grades, civilian decoration. * Order of the White Eagle (白鷹勳章): 9 grades. * Order of the Striped Tiger (文虎勳章): 9 grades, military decoration. * Order of Cloud and Crane (雲鶴勳章) * Order of the Golden Lion (金獅勳章) * Order of the Nebula (星雲勳章) * Order of the Begonia (棠勳章) * Medal of Compassion (慈惠章): awarded to women in charitable works. Various warlords also issued their own orders and commemorative medals. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== *[http://www.mnd.gov.tw/people/f/index.htm ''Explanation of Decorations''. Department of Public Service, Ministry of National Defense, ROC.] *[http://www.medals.org.uk/taiwan/taiwan-text.htm ''Orders, Decorations and Medals of Taiwan (Republic of China)''. Medals of the World.] *[http://www.president.gov.tw/1_art/subject-02.html ''National Seal and Orders''. Office of the President, Republic of China (Taiwan).] {{Orders, decorations and medals of the Republic of China}} {{Decorations by country}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Orders, Decorations And Medals Of The Republic Of China}} [[Category:Orders, decorations, and medals of the Republic of China]] [[Category:Republic of China-related lists|Ord]] [[Category:Lists of orders, decorations, and medals]]

<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of Anguilla-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of Anguilla.svg|227|Coat of Arms of Anguilla.svg|89|The [[Flag of Anguilla]]|The [[Coat of arms of Anguilla]]}} [[image:LocationAnguilla.png|thumb|The location of [[Anguilla]]]] [[image:Anguilla map.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[British Overseas Territory]] of [[Anguilla]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Anguilla:
'''[[Anguilla]]''' – one of the most northerly of the [[Leeward Islands]] in the [[Lesser Antilles]], lying east of [[Puerto Rico]] and the [[Virgin Islands]] and directly north of [[Saint Martin]]. Anguilla has become a popular tax haven, having no capital gains, estate, profit or other forms of direct taxation on either individuals or corporations.<ref>{{cite web|author=Tax Rates |url=http://www.taxrates.cc/html/anguilla-tax-rates.html |title=Anguilla Tax Rates |publisher=Taxrates.cc |date= |accessdate=2011-12-28}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
==General reference== <!-- [[image:Anguilla map.png|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Anguilla]]]] --> * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]: * Common English country name: [[Anguilla]] * Official English country name: [[Anguilla]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Anguillan (disambiguation)]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[ISO country codes]]: AI, AIA, 660 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:AI]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.ai]]
== Geography of Anguilla == <!-- [[image:???|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Anguilla]]]] -->
[[Geography of Anguilla]] * Anguilla is: an [[island]] and [[British overseas territory]] consisting of it and a number of smaller [[island]]s and [[cay]]s. * Location: ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] and [[Western Hemisphere]] *** [[North America]] (off the [[East Coast of the United States]], southeast of [[Puerto Rico]]) ** [[Atlantic Ocean]] *** [[Caribbean]] **** [[Antilles]] ***** [[Lesser Antilles]] (island chain) ****** [[Leeward Islands]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[Eastern Caribbean Time]] ([[UTC-04]]) ** Extreme points of Anguilla *** High: [[Crocus Hill]] {{convert|65|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Caribbean Sea]] 0 m ** Land boundaries: ''none'' ** Coastline: 61 km * [[Population of Anguilla]]: 13,477 (2006) - [[List of countries by population|212th most populous country]] * [[Area of Anguilla]]: {{convert|102|km2|sqmi}} - [[List of countries and outlying territories by total area|220th largest country]] * [[:commons:Atlas of Anguilla|Atlas of Anguilla]]
=== Environment of Anguilla === <!-- [[image:???|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Anguilla]]]] -->
* [[Climate of Anguilla]] * [[Renewable energy in Anguilla]] * [[Geology of Anguilla]] * [[Protected areas of Anguilla]] ** [[List of biosphere reserves in Anguilla|Biosphere reserves in Anguilla]] ** [[List of national parks of Anguilla|National parks of Anguilla]] * [[Wildlife of Anguilla]] ** [[Fauna of Anguilla]] *** [[List of birds of Anguilla|Birds of Anguilla]] *** [[List of mammals of Anguilla|Mammals of Anguilla]]
==== Natural geographic features of Anguilla ====
* [[Fjords of Anguilla]] * [[Glaciers of Anguilla]] * [[List of islands of Anguilla|Islands of Anguilla]] * [[List of lakes in Anguilla|Lakes of Anguilla]] * [[List of mountains of Anguilla|Mountains of Anguilla]] ** [[List of volcanoes in Anguilla|Volcanoes in Anguilla]] * [[List of rivers of Anguilla|Rivers of Anguilla]] ** [[List of waterfalls of Anguilla|Waterfalls of Anguilla]] * [[List of valleys of Anguilla|Valleys of Anguilla]] * World Heritage Sites in Anguilla: None
=== Regions of Anguilla ===
[[Regions of Anguilla]]
==== Ecoregions of Anguilla ====
[[List of ecoregions in Anguilla]] ====Administrative divisions of Anguilla====
[[Administrative divisions of Anguilla]] * [[Municipalities of Anguilla]]
===== Municipalities of Anguilla =====
[[Municipalities of Anguilla]] * [[Capital (political)|Capital]] of Anguilla: [[Capital of Anguilla|The Valley]] * [[List of villages in Anguilla|Villages of Anguilla]]
=== Demography of Anguilla ===
[[Demographics of Anguilla]]
== Government and politics of Anguilla ==
[[Politics of Anguilla]] * [[Form of government]]: [[parliamentary system|parliamentary]] [[representative democracy|representative democratic]] [[Dependent territory|dependency]] * [[Capital (political)|Capital]] of Anguilla: [[Capital of Anguilla|The Valley]] * [[Elections in Anguilla]] * [[List of political parties in Anguilla|Political parties in Anguilla]]
===Branches of government===
[[Government of Anguilla]] ==== Executive branch of the government of Anguilla ==== * [[Head of state]]: [[Monarch of the United Kingdom]], [[Queen Elizabeth II]] ** Monarch's representative: [[Governor of Anguilla]] * [[Head of government]]: [[Chief Minister of Anguilla]] * Cabinet of Anguilla
==== Legislative branch of the government of Anguilla ====
* [[Anguilla House of Assembly]]
==== Judicial branch of the government of Anguilla ====
[[Court system of Anguilla]] * [[Supreme Court of Anguilla]]
=== Foreign relations of Anguilla ===
[[Foreign relations of Anguilla]] * [[List of diplomatic missions in Anguilla|Diplomatic missions in Anguilla]] * [[Diplomatic missions of Anguilla]]
==== International organization membership ==== Anguilla is a member of:<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 3, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/av.html|title=Anguilla|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> *[[Caribbean Community and Common Market]] (Caricom) (associate) *[[Caribbean Development Bank]] (CDB) *[[International Criminal Police Organization]] (Interpol) (subbureau) *[[Organization of Eastern Caribbean States]] (OECS) *[[Universal Postal Union]] (UPU) *[[World Federation of Trade Unions]] (WFTU)
=== Law and order in Anguilla ===
[[Law of Anguilla]]
=== Military of Anguilla ===
[[Military of Anguilla]] * Anguilla has no military of its own: Anguilla is a [[protectorate]] of the [[United Kingdom]] (UK), and the UK is responsible for its military defense. * Command ** [[Commander-in-chief]] *** [[Ministry of Defence (Anguilla)|Ministry of Defence of Anguilla]] * Forces ** [[Army]] of Anguilla: none ** [[Navy]] of Anguilla: none ** [[Air Force]] of Anguilla: none ** [[Special forces]] of Anguilla: none * [[Military history of Anguilla]] * [[Military ranks of Anguilla]]
=== Local government in Anguilla ===
[[Local government in Anguilla]] == History of Anguilla ==
[[History of Anguilla]] *[[Timeline of the history of Anguilla]] *[[Portal:Current events/Anguilla|Current events of Anguilla]] * [[Military history of Anguilla]]
== Culture of Anguilla ==
[[Culture of Anguilla]] * [[Architecture of Anguilla]] * [[Cuisine of Anguilla]] * [[Festivals in Anguilla]] * [[Languages of Anguilla]] * [[Media in Anguilla]] * [[National symbols of Anguilla]] ** [[Coat of arms of Anguilla]] ** [[Flag of Anguilla]] ** [[National anthem of Anguilla]] * [[People of Anguilla]] * [[Public holidays in Anguilla]] * [[List of records of Anguilla|Records of Anguilla]] * [[Religion in Anguilla]] ** [[Christianity in Anguilla]] ** [[Hinduism in Anguilla]] ** [[Islam in Anguilla]] ** [[Judaism in Anguilla]] ** [[Sikhism in Anguilla]] * World Heritage Sites in Anguilla: None
=== Art in Anguilla === * [[Art in Anguilla]] * [[Cinema of Anguilla]] * [[Literature of Anguilla]] * [[Music of Anguilla]] * [[Television in Anguilla]] * [[Theatre in Anguilla]]
=== Sports in Anguilla ===
[[Sports in Anguilla]] * [[Football in Anguilla]] * [[Anguilla at the Olympics]]
==Economy and infrastructure of Anguilla ==
[[Economy of Anguilla]] * [[List of countries by GDP (nominal)|Economic rank, by nominal GDP (2007)]]: 188th (one hundred and eighty eighth) * [[Communications in Anguilla]] ** [[Internet in Anguilla]] * [[List of companies of Anguilla|Companies of Anguilla]] *[[Currency|Currency of Anguilla]]: [[East Caribbean dollar|Dollar]] **[[ISO 4217]]: XCD * [[Anguilla Stock Exchange]] * [[Transport in Anguilla]] ** [[List of airports in Anguilla|Airports in Anguilla]]
== Education in Anguilla ==
[[Education in Anguilla]] *[[List of schools in Anguilla]] *[[Saint James School of Medicine]]

Making it invisible, but leaving it here in case it is a temporary problem: * [http://www.freeanguilla.com/ Free Anguilla] - A Network of Anguilla Forums (non partisan discussion)--->

{{Infobox subdivision type | name = Parishes
Parròquies d'Andorra | alt_name = |map = [[File:Andora.png|250px]] |category = [[Unitary state]] |territory = [[Principality of Andorra]] |start_date = |current_number =7 Parishes |number_date = |population_range = 5,422 [[Ordino]] – 22,256 [[Andorra la Vella]] |area_range = {{Convert|12|sqkm|abbr=on}} [[Andorra la Vella]] – {{Convert|20494|sqkm|abbr=on}} [[Canillo]] |government = [[Politics of Andorra#Administrative divisions|Parish government]] |subdivision = Village }} {{Politics of Andorra}} '''[[Andorra]]''' consists of seven communities known as '''parishes''' ({{lang-ca|'''parròquies'''}}, singular{{spaced ndash}}'''parròquia'''). Until relatively recently, it had only six parishes; the seventh, Escaldes-Engordany, was created in 1978. ==Overview== [[Andorra la Vella]] is the capital of Andorra. Some parishes have a further territorial subdivision; [[Ordino]], [[La Massana]] and [[Sant Julià de Lòria]] are subdivided into ''quarts'' (quarters), while [[Canillo]] is subdivided into 10 ''veïnats'' (neighborhoods). Those mostly coincide with [[village]]s, which are found in all parishes. Each parish has its own elected mayor who is the nominal head of the local government known as a ''comú'' in Catalan. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! rowspan=2 scope="col"| Parish ! rowspan=2 scope="col"| ISO 3166-2 ! [[Image:Coat of arms of Andorra.svg|x50px|link=Andorra|alt=Coat of arms of Andorra]] [[Andorra]] ! {{Infobox official post |post = Premier of the Cayman Islands |body = |nativename = |flag = |flagsize = |flagcaption = |insignia = Coat of arms of the Cayman Islands.svg |insigniasize = |insigniacaption = '''[[Coat of arms of the Cayman Islands|Arms of]] [[Her Majesty's Government (term)|Her Majesty's]]
[[Politics of the Cayman Islands|Cayman Islands Government]]''' |image = Alden McLaughlin, Premier, Cayman Islands.jpg |imagesize = |alt = |incumbent = [[Alden McLaughlin]] |incumbentsince = 29 May 2013 |department = |style = [[The Honourable]] |member_of = |reports_to = |residence = |seat = |nominator = |appointer = [[Governor of the Cayman Islands]] |appointer_qualified = |termlength = [[At Her Majesty's pleasure|At the Governor's pleasure]] |termlength_qualified = |constituting_instrument = |precursor = |formation = November 1992 |first = [[Thomas Jefferson (Caymanian politician)|Thomas Jefferson]]
as Leader of Government Business |last = |abolished = |succession = |deputy = |salary = |website = [http://www.gov.ky/portal/page?_pageid=1142,1595737&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL/ Office of the Premier] }} {{Politics of the Cayman Islands}} The '''Premier of the Cayman Islands''' is the political leader and [[head of government]]. The post of Premier in the [[Cayman Islands]] is the equivalent to [[Chief Minister]] or [[Prime Minister]] in other [[British Overseas Territories]]. It is the highest political level that can be attained within the British overseas territory. Prior to 2009, the position was known as '''Leader of Government Business'''. The Premier and Cabinet (consisting of all the most senior ministers) are collectively accountable for their policies and actions to Queen [[Elizabeth II]], to the [[Legislative Assembly of the Cayman Islands|Legislative Assembly]], to their political party and ultimately to the electorate. The current Premier is [[Alden McLaughlin]], since 29 May 2013. ==Constitutional background== Until 2001 the position had no official recognition, but it was formalized by an Order of the British Government in July 2001, as the Leader of Government Business along with the [[Opposition (parliamentary)|Leader of the Opposition]]. Further constitutional amendments in 2009 modified the name to Premier. ==List== (Dates in italics indicate ''de facto'' continuation of office) {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- align=center bgcolor=#ebebeb !rowspan=2|№ !rowspan=2|Name
{{small|(Birth–Death)}} !colspan=2|Tenure !rowspan=2|Political Affiliation !rowspan=2|Notes |- align=center bgcolor=#ebebeb !Took Office !Left Office |- ! colspan=6| Leaders of Government Business (1992–2009) |- ! style="background:{{Independent (politician)/meta/color}}; color:black"| 1 | [[Thomas Jefferson (Caymanian politician)|Thomas Jefferson]]
{{small|(1941–2006)}} | November 1992 | November 1994 | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | |- ! style="background:{{Independent (politician)/meta/color}}; color:black"| 2 | [[Truman Bodden]]
{{small|(1945–)}} | November 1994 | 8 November 2000 | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | |- ! style="background:{{Independent (politician)/meta/color}}; color:black"| 3 | [[Kurt Tibbetts]]
{{small|(1954–)}} | 8 November 2000 | 8 November 2001 | [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] | {{small|First tenure}} |- ! style="background:Green; color:white"| 4 | [[McKeeva Bush]]
{{small|(1955–)}} | 8 November 2001 | 18 May 2005 | [[United Democratic Party (Cayman Islands)|United Democratic Party]] | {{small|First tenure}} |- ! style="background:Red; color:white"| {{small|(3)}} | [[Kurt Tibbetts]]
{{small|(1954–)}} | 18 May 2005 | 27 May 2009 | [[People's Progressive Movement (Cayman Islands)|People's Progressive Movement]] | {{small|Second tenure}} |- ! style="background:Green; color:white"| {{small|(4)}} | [[McKeeva Bush]]
{{small|(1955–)}} | 27 May 2009 | ''6 November 2009'' | [[United Democratic Party (Cayman Islands)|United Democratic Party]] | {{small|Second tenure}} |- ! colspan=6| Premiers (2009–present) |- ! style="background:Green; color:white"| 1 | [[McKeeva Bush]]
